values.name: normal
values.description: Indicates that text is laid out using default font settings. This is the default value.

values.name: off
values.description: Disable feature.

values.name: on
values.description: Enable feature.

properties.description: The font-feature-settings CSS property controls advanced typographic features in OpenType fonts.

properties.name: font-kerning

values.name: auto
values.description: The browser determines whether font kerning should be used or not. For example, some browsers will disable kerning on small fonts, since applying it could harm the readability of text.

values.name: none
values.description: Font kerning information stored in the font is disabled.

values.name: normal
values.description: Font kerning information stored in the font must be applied.

properties.description: The font-kerning CSS property sets the use of the kerning information stored in a font.

properties.name: font-language-override

values.name: normal
values.description: Tells the browser to use font glyphs that are appropriate for the language specified by the lang attribute. This is the default value.

properties.description: The font-language-override CSS property controls the use of language-specific glyphs in a typeface.

properties.name: font-optical-sizing

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: none
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The font-optical-sizing CSS property sets whether text rendering is optimized for viewing at different sizes.

properties.name: font-palette
properties.description: The font-palette CSS property allows specifying one of the many palettes contained in a font that a user agent should use for the font. Users can also override the values in a palette or create a new palette by using the @font-palette-values at-rule.

values.name: normal
values.description: Specifies the default color palette or the default glyph colorization (set by the font maker) to be used for the font. With this setting, the palette in the font at index 0 is rendered.

values.name: light
values.description: Specifies the first palette in the font that matches 'light' to be used for the font. Some fonts contain metadata that identify a palette as applicable for a light (close to white) background. If a font does not have this metadata, the light value behaves as normal.

values.name: dark
values.description: Specifies the first palette in the font that matches 'dark' to be used for the font. Some fonts contain metadata that identify a palette as applicable for a dark (close to black) background. If a font does not have this metadata, the value behaves as normal.

properties.name: font-size-adjust

values.name: none
values.description: No adjustment is applied to the font-size value for the fallback font.

values.name: from-font
values.description: Uses the <number> value for the specified <font-metric> from the first available font.

values.name: ex-height
values.description: Uses the ratio of x-height (height of lowercase "x" in a font) to font size (aspect value) to adjust the fallback font size. This keyword value is used to normalize lowercase letters across fonts.

values.name: cap-height
values.description: Uses the ratio of cap-height (height of uppercase letters) to font size to adjust fallback font size. This keyword value is used to normalize uppercase letters across fonts.

values.name: ch-width
values.description: Uses the ratio of the advance width (horizontal space taken up by a character in a font) of the character "0" (ZERO, U+0030) to font size. This keyword value is used to normalize horizontal narrow pitch of fonts.

values.name: ic-width
values.description: Uses the ratio of the advance width of the character "水" (CJK water ideograph, U+6C34) to font size. This keyword value is used to normalize horizontal wide pitch of fonts, particularly those that include CJK (Chinese, Japanese, Korean) characters.

values.name: ic-height
values.description: Uses the ratio of the advance height (vertical space taken up by a character in a font) of the character "水" (CJK water ideograph, U+6C34) to font size. This keyword value is used to normalize vertical wide pitch of fonts, particularly those that include CJK characters.

properties.syntax: none | [ ex-height | cap-height | ch-width | ic-width | ic-height ]? [ from-font | <number> ]
properties.description: The font-size-adjust CSS property provides a way to modify the size of lowercase letters relative to the size of uppercase letters, which defines the overall font-size. This property is useful for situations where font fallback can occur.

properties.name: font-smooth
properties.description: The font-smooth CSS property controls the application of anti-aliasing when fonts are rendered.

properties.name: font-stretch

values.name: condensed
values.description: Specifies a more condensed font face than normal, with ultra-condensed as the most condensed.

values.name: expanded
values.description: Specifies a more expanded font face than normal, with ultra-expanded as the most expanded.

values.name: extra-condensed
values.description: Specifies a more condensed font face than normal, with ultra-condensed as the most condensed.

values.name: extra-expanded
values.description: Specifies a more expanded font face than normal, with ultra-expanded as the most expanded.

values.name: narrower
values.description: Indicates a narrower value relative to the width of the parent element.

values.name: normal
values.description: Specifies a normal font face.

values.name: semi-condensed
values.description: Specifies a more condensed font face than normal, with ultra-condensed as the most condensed.

values.name: semi-expanded
values.description: Specifies a more expanded font face than normal, with ultra-expanded as the most expanded.

values.name: ultra-condensed
values.description: Specifies a more condensed font face than normal, with ultra-condensed as the most condensed.

values.name: ultra-expanded
values.description: Specifies a more expanded font face than normal, with ultra-expanded as the most expanded.

values.name: wider
values.description: Indicates a wider value relative to the width of the parent element.

properties.description: The font-stretch CSS property selects a normal, condensed, or expanded face from a font.

properties.name: font-synthesis

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that no bold, italic, or small-caps typeface may be synthesized by the browser.

values.name: style
values.description: Indicates that the italic typeface may be synthesized by the browser if needed.

values.name: weight
values.description: Indicates that the missing bold typeface may be synthesized by the browser if needed.

values.name: small-caps
values.description: Indicates that the small-caps typeface may be synthesized by the browser if needed.

values.name: position
values.description: Indicates that the subscript and superscript typeface may be synthesized by the browser, if needed, when using font-variant-position.

properties.description: The font-synthesis shorthand CSS property lets you specify whether or not the browser may synthesize the bold, italic, small-caps, and/or subscript and superscript typefaces when they are missing in the specified font-family.

properties.name: font-synthesis-position

values.name: auto
values.description: Indicates that a missing position typeface may be synthesized by the browser if needed.

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that the synthesis of a missing position typeface by the browser is not allowed.

properties.description: The font-synthesis-position CSS property lets you specify whether or not a browser may synthesize the subscript and superscript "position" typefaces when they are missing in a font family, while using font-variant-position to set the positions.

properties.name: font-synthesis-small-caps

values.name: auto
values.description: Indicates that the missing small-caps typeface may be synthesized by the browser if needed.

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that the synthesis of the missing small-caps typeface by the browser is not allowed.

properties.description: The font-synthesis-small-caps CSS property lets you specify whether or not the browser may synthesize small-caps typeface when it is missing in a font family. Small-caps glyphs typically use the form of uppercase letters but are reduced to the size of lowercase letters.

properties.name: font-synthesis-style

values.name: auto
values.description: Indicates that the missing oblique typeface may be synthesized by the browser if needed.

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that the synthesis of the missing oblique typeface by the browser is not allowed.

properties.description: The font-synthesis-style CSS property lets you specify whether or not the browser may synthesize the oblique typeface when it is missing in a font family.

properties.name: font-synthesis-weight

values.name: auto
values.description: Indicates that the missing bold typeface may be synthesized by the browser if needed.

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that the synthesis of the missing bold typeface by the browser is not allowed.

properties.description: The font-synthesis-weight CSS property lets you specify whether or not the browser may synthesize the bold typeface when it is missing in a font family.

properties.name: font-variant

values.name: normal
values.description: Specifies a normal font face. Each longhand property has an initial value of normal.

values.name: small-caps
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.

values.name: none
values.description: Sets the value of the font-variant-ligatures as none and the values of the other longhand properties as normal, their initial value.

values.name: stylistic()
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.

values.name: historical-forms
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.

values.name: styleset()
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.

values.name: character-variant()
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.

values.name: swash()
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.

values.name: ornaments()
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.

values.name: annotation()
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-ligatures longhand property.

values.name: all-small-caps
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.

values.name: petite-caps
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.

values.name: all-petite-caps
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.

values.name: unicase
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.

values.name: titling-caps
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-caps longhand property. The small-caps value is the only non-normal font variant valid within the font shorthand property.

values.name: ordinal
values.description: Specifies the keywords related to the font-variant-numeric longhand property. The possible values are lining-nums, oldstyle-nums, proportional-nums, tabular-nums, diagonal-fractions, stacked-fractions, ordinal, and slashed-zero.

values.name: slashed-zero
values.description: Specifies the keywords related to the font-variant-numeric longhand property. The possible values are lining-nums, oldstyle-nums, proportional-nums, tabular-nums, diagonal-fractions, stacked-fractions, ordinal, and slashed-zero.

values.name: ruby
values.description: Specifies the keywords related to the font-variant-east-asian longhand property. The possible values are jis78, jis83, jis90, jis04, simplified, traditional, full-width, proportional-width, and ruby.

values.name: sub
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-position longhand property.

values.name: super
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-position longhand property.

values.name: text
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-emoji longhand property.

values.name: emoji
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-emoji longhand property.

values.name: unicode
values.description: Specifies the keywords and functions related to the font-variant-emoji longhand property.

properties.syntax: normal | none | [ <common-lig-values> || <discretionary-lig-values> || <historical-lig-values> || <contextual-alt-values> || stylistic(<feature-value-name>) || historical-forms || styleset(<feature-value-name>#) || character-variant(<feature-value-name>#) || swash(<feature-value-name>) || ornaments(<feature-value-name>) || annotation(<feature-value-name>) || [ small-caps | all-small-caps | petite-caps | all-petite-caps | unicase | titling-caps ] || <numeric-figure-values> || <numeric-spacing-values> || <numeric-fraction-values> || ordinal || slashed-zero || <east-asian-variant-values> || <east-asian-width-values> || ruby ]
properties.description: The font-variant CSS shorthand property allows you to set all the font variants for a font.

properties.name: font-variant-alternates

values.name: annotation()
values.description: This function enables annotations, like circled digits or inverted characters. The parameter is a font-specific name mapped to a number. It corresponds to the OpenType value nalt, like nalt 2.

values.name: character-variant()
values.description: This function enables specific stylistic alternatives for characters. It is similar to styleset(), but doesn't create coherent glyphs for a set of characters; individual characters will have independent and not necessarily coherent styles. The parameter is a font-specific name mapped to a number. It corresponds to the OpenType value cvXY, like cv02.

values.name: historical-forms
values.description: This keyword enables historical forms — glyphs that were common in the past but not today. It corresponds to the OpenType value hist.

values.name: normal
values.description: This keyword deactivates alternate glyphs.

values.name: ornaments()
values.description:
This function enables ornaments, like fleurons and other dingbat glyphs. The parameter is a font-specific name mapped to a number. It corresponds to the OpenType value ornm, like ornm 2.
    
      Note: In order to preserve text semantics, font designers should include ornaments that don't match Unicode dingbat characters as ornamental variants of the bullet character (U+2022). Be aware that some existing fonts don't follow this advice.

values.name: styleset()
values.description: This function enables stylistic alternatives for sets of characters. The parameter is a font-specific name mapped to a number. It corresponds to the OpenType value ssXY, like ss02.

values.name: stylistic()
values.description: This function enables stylistic alternates for individual characters. The parameter is a font-specific name mapped to a number. It corresponds to the OpenType value salt, like salt 2.

values.name: swash()
values.description: This function enables swash glyphs. The parameter is a font-specific name mapped to a number. It corresponds to the OpenType values swsh and cswh, like swsh 2 and cswh 2.

properties.syntax: normal | [ stylistic( <feature-value-name> ) || historical-forms || styleset( <feature-value-name># ) || character-variant( <feature-value-name># ) || swash( <feature-value-name> ) || ornaments( <feature-value-name> ) || annotation( <feature-value-name> ) ]
properties.description: The font-variant-alternates CSS property controls the usage of alternate glyphs. These alternate glyphs may be referenced by alternative names defined in @font-feature-values.

properties.name: font-variant-caps

values.name: all-petite-caps
values.description: Enables display of petite capitals for both upper and lowercase letters (OpenType features: c2pc, pcap).

values.name: all-small-caps
values.description: Enables display of small capitals for both upper and lowercase letters (OpenType features: c2sc, smcp).

values.name: normal
values.description: Deactivates of the use of alternate glyphs.

values.name: petite-caps
values.description: Enables display of petite capitals (OpenType feature: pcap).

values.name: small-caps
values.description: Enables display of small capitals (OpenType feature: smcp). Small-caps glyphs typically use the form of uppercase letters but are displayed using the same size as lowercase letters.

values.name: titling-caps
values.description: Enables display of titling capitals (OpenType feature: titl). Uppercase letter glyphs are often designed for use with lowercase letters. When used in all uppercase titling sequences they can appear too strong. Titling capitals are designed specifically for this situation.

values.name: unicase
values.description: Enables display of mixture of small capitals for uppercase letters with normal lowercase letters (OpenType feature: unic).

properties.syntax: normal | small-caps | all-small-caps | petite-caps | all-petite-caps | unicase | titling-caps
properties.description: The font-variant-caps CSS property controls the use of alternate glyphs for capital letters.

properties.name: font-variant-east-asian

values.name: full-width
values.description: Enables rendering of full-width variants.

values.name: jis04
values.description: Enables rendering of JIS04 forms.

values.name: jis78
values.description: Enables rendering of JIS78 forms.

values.name: jis83
values.description: Enables rendering of JIS83 forms.

values.name: jis90
values.description: Enables rendering of JIS90 forms.

values.name: normal
values.description: This keyword leads to the deactivation of the use of such alternate glyphs.

values.name: proportional-width
values.description: Enables rendering of proportionally-spaced variants.

values.name: ruby
values.description: This keyword forces the use of special glyphs for ruby characters. As these are usually smaller, font creators often designs specific forms, usually slightly bolder to improve the contrast. This keyword corresponds to the OpenType values ruby.

values.name: simplified
values.description: Enables rendering of simplified forms.

values.name: traditional
values.description: Enables rendering of traditional forms.

properties.description: The font-variant-east-asian CSS property controls the use of alternate glyphs for East Asian scripts, like Japanese and Chinese.

properties.name: font-variant-emoji

values.name: normal
values.description: Allows a browser to choose how to display the emoji. This often follows the operating system setting.

values.name: text
values.description: Renders the emoji as if it were using the unicode text variation selector (U+FE0E).

values.name: emoji
values.description: Renders the emoji as if it were using the unicode emoji variation selector (U+FE0F).

values.name: unicode
values.description: Renders the emoji in accordance with the Emoji presentation properties. If the U+FE0E or U+FE0F variation selector is present, then it will override this value setting.

properties.description: The font-variant-emoji CSS property specifies the default presentation style for displaying emojis.

properties.name: font-variant-ligatures

values.name: additional-ligatures
values.description: Enables display of additional ligatures.

values.name: common-ligatures
values.description: Enables display of common ligatures.

values.name: contextual
values.description: Enables display of contextual alternates.

values.name: discretionary-ligatures
values.description: Enables display of discretionary ligatures.

values.name: historical-ligatures
values.description: Enables display of historical ligatures.

values.name: no-additional-ligatures
values.description: Disables display of additional ligatures.

values.name: no-common-ligatures
values.description: Disables display of common ligatures.

values.name: no-contextual
values.description: Disables display of contextual alternates.

values.name: no-discretionary-ligatures
values.description: Disables display of discretionary ligatures.

values.name: no-historical-ligatures
values.description: Disables display of historical ligatures.

values.name: none
values.description: This keyword specifies that all ligatures and contextual forms are disabled, even common ones.

values.name: normal
values.description: This keyword leads to the activation of the usual ligatures and contextual forms needed for correct rendering. The ligatures and forms activated depend on the font, language and kind of script. This is the default value.

properties.description: The font-variant-ligatures CSS property controls which ligatures and contextual forms are used in textual content of the elements it applies to. This leads to more harmonized forms in the resulting text.

properties.name: font-variant-numeric

values.name: diagonal-fractions
values.description: Enables display of lining diagonal fractions.

values.name: lining-nums
values.description: Enables display of lining numerals.

values.name: normal
values.description: This keyword leads to the deactivation of the use of such alternate glyphs.

values.name: oldstyle-nums
values.description: Enables display of old-style numerals.

values.name: ordinal
values.description: This keyword forces the use of special glyphs for the ordinal markers, like 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th in English or a 1a in Italian. It corresponds to the OpenType values ordn.

values.name: proportional-nums
values.description: Enables display of proportional numerals.

values.name: slashed-zero
values.description: This keyword forces the use of a 0 with a slash; this is useful when a clear distinction between O and 0 is needed. It corresponds to the OpenType values zero.

values.name: stacked-fractions
values.description: Enables display of lining stacked fractions.

values.name: tabular-nums
values.description: Enables display of tabular numerals.

properties.description: The font-variant-numeric CSS property controls the usage of alternate glyphs for numbers, fractions, and ordinal markers.

properties.name: font-variant-position

values.name: normal
values.description: Deactivates alternate superscript and subscript glyphs.

values.name: sub
values.description: Activates subscript alternate glyphs. If, in a given run, one such glyph is not available for a character, all the characters in the run are rendered using synthesized glyphs.

values.name: super
values.description: Activates superscript alternate glyphs. If, in a given run, one such glyph is not available for a character, all the characters in the run are rendered using synthesized glyphs.

properties.description: The font-variant-position CSS property controls the use of alternate, smaller glyphs that are positioned as superscript or subscript.

properties.name: font-variation-settings
properties.description: The font-variation-settings CSS property provides low-level control over variable font characteristics by letting you specify the four letter axis names of the characteristics you want to vary along with their values.

values.name: normal
values.description: Text is laid out using default settings.

properties.name: forced-color-adjust

values.name: auto
values.description: The element's colors are adjusted by the user agent in forced colors mode. This is the default.

values.name: none
values.description: The element's colors are not automatically adjusted by the user agent in forced colors mode.

properties.description: The forced-color-adjust CSS property allows authors to opt certain elements out of forced colors mode. This then restores the control of those values to CSS.

properties.name: gap
properties.description: The gap CSS shorthand property sets the gaps (gutters) between rows and columns.

properties.name: glyph-orientation-horizontal
properties.description: Controls glyph orientation when the inline-progression-direction is horizontal.

properties.name: glyph-orientation-vertical

values.name: auto
values.description: Sets the orientation based on the fullwidth or non-fullwidth characters and the most common orientation.

properties.description: Controls glyph orientation when the inline-progression-direction is vertical.

properties.name: grid
properties.description: The grid CSS property is a shorthand property that sets all of the explicit and implicit grid properties in a single declaration.

values.name: grid-template-rows
values.description: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。

values.name: grid-template-columns
values.description: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。

values.name: none
values.description: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。

values.name: grid-auto-columns
values.description: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。

values.name: grid-auto-rows
values.description: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。

values.name: grid-auto-flow
values.description: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。

values.name: column
values.description: 所有其余 grid 次级属性被重置为初始值。

properties.name: grid-area

values.name: auto
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement or a default span of 1.

values.name: span
values.description: Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.

values.name: span && [ <integer> || <custom-ident> ]
values.description:
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the opposite edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or 0 are invalid.

properties.description: The grid-area CSS shorthand property specifies a grid item's size and location within a grid by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the edges of its grid area.

properties.name: grid-auto-columns

values.name: min-content
values.description: Is a keyword representing the largest minimal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.

values.name: max-content
values.description: Is a keyword representing the largest maximal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.

values.name: auto
values.description:
As a maximum represents the largest max-content size of the items in that track.
    As a minimum represents the largest minimum size of items in that track (specified by the min-width/min-height of the items). This is often, though not always, the min-content size.
    If used outside of minmax() notation, auto represents the range between the minimum and maximum described above. This behaves similarly to minmax(min-content,max-content) in most cases.
    
      Note: auto track sizes (and only auto track sizes) can be stretched by the align-content and justify-content properties. Therefore by default, an auto sized track will take up any remaining space in the grid container.

values.name: minmax()
values.description: Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.

values.name: minmax(min, max)
values.description: Is a functional notation that defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max. If max is smaller than min, then max is ignored and the function is treated as min. As a maximum, a <flex> value sets the track's flex factor. As a minimum, it is treated as zero (or minimal content, if the grid container is sized under a minimal content constraint).

values.name: fit-content( [ <length> | <percentage> ] )
values.description: Represents the formula min(max-content, max(auto, argument)), which is calculated similar to auto (i.e. minmax(auto, max-content)), except that the track size is clamped at argument if it is greater than the auto minimum.

values.name: fit-content(argument)
values.description: 相当于公式 min(max-content, max(auto, argument))，类似于auto 的计算 (即 minmax(auto, max-content))，除了网格轨道大小值是确定下来的，否则该值都大于 auto 的最小值。

properties.description: The grid-auto-columns CSS property specifies the size of an implicitly-created grid column track or pattern of tracks.

properties.name: grid-auto-flow

values.name: row
values.description: Items are placed by filling each row in turn, adding new rows as necessary. If neither row nor column is provided, row is assumed.

values.name: column
values.description: Items are placed by filling each column in turn, adding new columns as necessary.

values.name: dense
values.description:
"dense" packing algorithm attempts to fill in holes earlier in the grid, if smaller items come up later. This may cause items to appear out-of-order, when doing so would fill in holes left by larger items.
    If it is omitted, a "sparse" algorithm is used, where the placement algorithm only ever moves "forward" in the grid when placing items, never backtracking to fill holes. This ensures that all of the auto-placed items appear "in order", even if this leaves holes that could have been filled by later items.

properties.description: The grid-auto-flow CSS property controls how the auto-placement algorithm works, specifying exactly how auto-placed items get flowed into the grid.

properties.name: grid-auto-rows

values.name: min-content
values.description: Is a keyword representing the largest minimal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.

values.name: max-content
values.description: Is a keyword representing the largest maximal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.

values.name: auto
values.description:
As a maximum represents the largest max-content size of the items in that track.
    As a minimum represents the largest minimum size of items in that track (specified by the min-width/min-height of the items). This is often, though not always, the min-content size.
    If used outside of minmax() notation, auto represents the range between the minimum and maximum described above. This behaves similarly to minmax(min-content,max-content) in most cases.
    
      Note: auto track sizes (and only auto track sizes) can be stretched by the align-content and justify-content properties. Therefore by default, an auto sized track will take up any remaining space in the grid container.

values.name: minmax()
values.description: Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.

values.name: minmax(min, max)
values.description: Is a functional notation that defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max. If max is smaller than min, then max is ignored and the function is treated as min. As a maximum, a <flex> value sets the track's flex factor. As a minimum, it is treated as zero (or minimal content, if the grid container is sized under a minimal content constraint).

values.name: fit-content( [ <length> | <percentage> ] )
values.description: Represents the formula min(max-content, max(auto, argument)), which is calculated similar to auto (i.e. minmax(auto, max-content)), except that the track size is clamped at argument if it is greater than the auto minimum.

properties.description: The grid-auto-rows CSS property specifies the size of an implicitly-created grid row track or pattern of tracks.

properties.name: grid-column

values.name: auto
values.description: The property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of one.

values.name: span
values.description: Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.

properties.description: The grid-column CSS shorthand property specifies a grid item's size and location within a grid column by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the inline-start and inline-end edge of its grid area.

properties.name: grid-column-end

values.name: auto
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of 1.

values.name: span
values.description: Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.

values.name: span && [ <integer> || <custom-ident> ]
values.description:
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the column end edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the start edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or 0 are invalid.
    The <custom-ident> cannot take the span value.

properties.description: The grid-column-end CSS property specifies a grid item's end position within the grid column by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the block-end edge of its grid area.

properties.name: grid-column-gap
properties.description: Specifies the gutters between grid columns. Replaced by 'column-gap' property.

properties.name: grid-column-start

values.name: auto
values.description: A keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of 1.

values.name: span
values.description: Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.

values.name: span && [ <integer> || <custom-ident> ]
values.description:
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement, such that the column start edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the end edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers and 0 are invalid.
    The <custom-ident> cannot take the span value.

properties.description: The grid-column-start CSS property specifies a grid item's start position within the grid column by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement. This start position defines the block-start edge of the grid area.

properties.name: grid-gap
properties.description: Shorthand that specifies the gutters between grid columns and grid rows in one declaration. Replaced by 'gap' property.

properties.name: grid-row

values.name: auto
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of 1.

values.name: span
values.description: Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.

values.name: span && [ <integer> || <custom-ident> ]
values.description:
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the opposite edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or 0 are invalid.

properties.description: The grid-row CSS shorthand property specifies a grid item's size and location within a grid row by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the inline-start and inline-end edge of its grid area.

properties.name: grid-row-end

values.name: auto
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of 1.

values.name: span
values.description: Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.

values.name: span && [ <integer> || <custom-ident> ]
values.description:
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the row end edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the start edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid corresponding to the search direction are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or 0 are invalid.

properties.description: The grid-row-end CSS property specifies a grid item's end position within the grid row by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the inline-end edge of its grid area.

properties.name: grid-row-gap
properties.description: Specifies the gutters between grid rows. Replaced by 'row-gap' property.

properties.name: grid-row-start

values.name: auto
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the property contributes nothing to the grid item's placement, indicating auto-placement, an automatic span, or a default span of 1.

values.name: span
values.description: Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement such that the corresponding edge of the grid item's grid area is N lines from its opposite edge.

values.name: span && [ <integer> || <custom-ident> ]
values.description:
Contributes a grid span to the grid item's placement; such that the row start edge of the grid item's grid area is n lines from the end edge.
    If a name is given as a <custom-ident>, only lines with that name are counted. If not enough lines with that name exist, all implicit grid lines on the side of the explicit grid, corresponding to the search direction, are assumed to have that name for the purpose of counting this span.
    If the <integer> is omitted, it defaults to 1. Negative integers or 0 are invalid.
    The <custom-ident> cannot take the span value.

properties.description: The grid-row-start CSS property specifies a grid item's start position within the grid row by contributing a line, a span, or nothing (automatic) to its grid placement, thereby specifying the inline-start edge of its grid area.

properties.name: grid-template

values.name: none
values.description: Is a keyword that sets all three longhand properties to none, meaning there is no explicit grid. There are no named grid areas. Rows and columns will be implicitly generated; their size will be determined by the grid-auto-rows and grid-auto-columns properties.

values.name: min-content
values.description: Represents the largest min-content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.

values.name: max-content
values.description: Represents the largest max-content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.

values.name: auto
values.description: As a maximum, identical to 'max-content'. As a minimum, represents the largest minimum size (as specified by min-width/min-height) of the grid items occupying the grid track.

values.name: subgrid
values.description: Sets 'grid-template-rows' and 'grid-template-columns' to 'subgrid', and 'grid-template-areas' to its initial value.

values.name: minmax()
values.description: Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.

values.name: repeat()
values.description: Represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of columns or rows that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

values.name: [ <line-names>? <string> <track-size>? <line-names>? ]+ [ / <explicit-track-list> ]?
values.description:
Sets grid-template-areas to the strings listed, grid-template-rows to the track sizes following each string (filling in auto for any missing sizes), and splicing in the named lines defined before/after each size, and grid-template-columns to the track listing specified after the slash (or none, if not specified).
    
      Note: The repeat() function isn't allowed in these track listings, as the tracks are intended to visually line up one-to-one with the rows/columns in the "ASCII art".

properties.description: The grid-template CSS property is a shorthand property for defining grid columns, grid rows, and grid areas.

properties.name: grid-template-areas

values.name: none
values.description: The grid container doesn't define any named grid areas.

properties.description: The grid-template-areas CSS property specifies named grid areas, establishing the cells in the grid and assigning them names.

properties.name: grid-template-columns

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that there is no explicit grid. Any columns will be implicitly generated and their size will be determined by the grid-auto-columns property.

values.name: min-content
values.description: Is a keyword representing the largest minimal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track. For example, if the first element of the grid track contains the sentence "Repetitio est mater studiorum" and the second element contains the sentence "Dum spiro, spero", minimal content contribution will be defined by the size of the largest word among all of the sentences in the grid elements - "studiorum".

values.name: max-content
values.description: Is a keyword representing the largest maximal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track. For example, if the first element of the grid track contains the sentence "Repetitio est mater studiorum" and the second element contains the sentence "Dum spiro, spero", maximal content contribution will be defined by the size of the largest sentence among all of the grid elements - "Repetitio est mater studiorum".

values.name: auto
values.description:
As a maximum represents the largest max-content size of the items in that track.
    As a minimum represents the largest minimum size of items in that track (specified by the min-width/min-height of the items). This is often, though not always, the min-content size.
    If used outside of minmax() notation, auto represents the range between the minimum and maximum described above. This behaves similarly to minmax(min-content,max-content) in most cases.
    
      Note: auto track sizes (and only auto track sizes) can be stretched by the align-content and justify-content properties. Therefore by default, an auto sized track will take up any remaining space in the grid container.

values.name: subgrid
values.description: The subgrid value indicates that the grid will adopt the spanned portion of its parent grid in that axis. Rather than being specified explicitly, the sizes of the grid rows/columns will be taken from the parent grid's definition.

values.name: minmax()
values.description: Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.

values.name: repeat()
values.description: Represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of columns or rows that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

values.name: [linename]
values.description: A <custom-ident> specifying a name for the line in that location. The ident may be any valid string other than the reserved words span and auto. Lines may have multiple names separated by a space inside the square brackets, for example [line-name-a line-name-b].

values.name: minmax(min, max)
values.description: Is a functional notation that defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max. If max is smaller than min, then max is ignored and the function is treated as min. As a maximum, a <flex> value sets the track's flex factor. It is invalid as a minimum.

values.name: fit-content( [ <length> | <percentage> ] )
values.description: Represents the formula max(minimum, min(limit, max-content)), where minimum represents an auto minimum (which is often, but not always, equal to a min-content minimum), and limit is the track sizing function passed as an argument to fit-content(). This is essentially calculated as the smaller of minmax(auto, max-content) and minmax(auto, limit).

values.name: repeat( [ <positive-integer> | auto-fill | auto-fit ] , <track-list> )
values.description: Represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of columns that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

values.name: masonry
values.description: The masonry value indicates that this axis should be laid out according to the masonry algorithm.

properties.description: The grid-template-columns CSS property defines the line names and track sizing functions of the grid columns.

properties.name: grid-template-rows

values.name: none
values.description: Is a keyword meaning that there is no explicit grid. Any rows will be implicitly generated and their size will be determined by the grid-auto-rows property.

values.name: min-content
values.description: Is a keyword representing the largest minimal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.

values.name: max-content
values.description: Is a keyword representing the largest maximal content contribution of the grid items occupying the grid track.

values.name: auto
values.description:
As a maximum represents the largest max-content size of the items in that track.
    As a minimum represents the largest minimum size of items in that track (specified by the min-width/min-height of the items). This is often, though not always, the min-content size.
    If used outside of minmax() notation, auto represents the range between the minimum and maximum described above. This behaves similarly to minmax(min-content,max-content) in most cases.
    
      Note: auto track sizes (and only auto track sizes) can be stretched by the align-content and justify-content properties. Therefore by default, an auto sized track will take up any remaining space in the grid container.

values.name: subgrid
values.description: The subgrid value indicates that the grid will adopt the spanned portion of its parent grid in that axis. Rather than being specified explicitly, the sizes of the grid rows/columns will be taken from the parent grid's definition.

values.name: minmax()
values.description: Defines a size range greater than or equal to min and less than or equal to max.

values.name: repeat()
values.description: Represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of columns or rows that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

values.name: [linename]
values.description: A <custom-ident> specifying a name for the line in that location. The ident may be any valid string other than the reserved words span and auto. Lines may have multiple names separated by a space inside the square brackets, for example [line-name-a line-name-b].

values.name: minmax(min, max)
values.description: Is a functional notation that defines a size range, greater than or equal to min, and less than or equal to max. If max is smaller than min, then max is ignored and the function is treated as min. As a maximum, a <flex> value sets the track's flex factor. It is invalid as a minimum.

values.name: fit-content( [ <length> | <percentage> ] )
values.description: Represents the formula min(max-content, max(auto, argument)), which is calculated similar to auto (i.e. minmax(auto, max-content)), except that the track size is clamped at argument if it is greater than the auto minimum.

values.name: repeat( [ <positive-integer> | auto-fill | auto-fit ] , <track-list> )
values.description: Represents a repeated fragment of the track list, allowing a large number of rows that exhibit a recurring pattern to be written in a more compact form.

values.name: masonry
values.description: The masonry value indicates that this axis should be laid out according to the masonry algorithm.

properties.description: The grid-template-rows CSS property defines the line names and track sizing functions of the grid rows.

properties.name: hanging-punctuation
properties.description: The hanging-punctuation CSS property specifies whether a punctuation mark should hang at the start or end of a line of text. Hanging punctuation may be placed outside the line box.

values.name: none
values.description: No character hangs.

values.name: first
values.description:
An opening bracket or quote at the start of the first formatted line of an element hangs. This applies to:
    
      all characters in the Unicode categories Ps, Pf, Pi
      the quote marks U+0027 APOSTROPHE (') and U+0022 QUOTATION MARK (").

values.name: last
values.description:
A closing bracket or quote at the end of the last formatted line of an element hangs. This applies to:
    
      all characters in the Unicode categories Pe, Pf, Pi
      the quote marks U+0027 APOSTROPHE (') and U+0022 QUOTATION MARK (").

values.name: force-end
values.description: A stop or comma at the end of a line hangs.

values.name: allow-end
values.description: A stop or comma at the end of a line hangs if it does not otherwise fit prior to justification.

properties.name: hyphenate-character
properties.description: The hyphenate-character CSS property sets the character (or string) used at the end of a line before a hyphenation break.

values.name: auto
values.description:
The user-agent selects an appropriate string based on the content language's typographic conventions.
      This is the default property value, and only needs to be explicitly set in order to override a different inherited value.

properties.name: hyphenate-limit-chars
properties.description: The hyphenate-limit-chars CSS property specifies the minimum word length to allow hyphenation of words as well as the minimum number of characters before and after the hyphen.

values.name: x y z
values.description: The first value is the minimum word length before words should be hyphenated. The second value is the minimum number of characters before the hyphen. The third value is the minimum number of characters after the hyphen.

values.name: x y
values.description: The first value is the minimum word length before words should be hyphenated. The second value is the minimum number of characters before the hyphen. The minimum number of characters after the hyphen will be set equal to the second value.

values.name: x
values.description: The value is the minimum word length before words should be hyphenated. The minimum number of characters before and after the hyphen will be set to auto.

properties.name: hyphens

values.name: auto
values.description: The browser is free to automatically break words at appropriate hyphenation points, following whatever rules it chooses. However, suggested line break opportunities (see Suggesting line break opportunities below) will override automatic break point selection when present.

values.name: manual
values.description: Default value. Words are broken for line-wrapping only where characters inside the word suggest line break opportunities. See Suggesting line break opportunities below for details.

values.name: none
values.description: Words are not broken at line breaks, even if characters inside the words suggest line break points. Lines will only wrap at whitespace.

properties.description: The hyphens CSS property specifies how words should be hyphenated when text wraps across multiple lines. It can prevent hyphenation entirely, hyphenate at manually-specified points within the text, or let the browser automatically insert hyphens where appropriate.

properties.name: image-orientation

values.name: flip
values.description: After rotating by the precededing angle, the image is flipped horizontally. Defaults to 0deg if the angle is ommitted.

values.name: from-image
values.description: Default initial value. The EXIF information contained in the image is used to rotate the image appropriately.

values.name: none
values.description: Does not apply any additional image rotation; the image is oriented as encoded or as other CSS property values dictate.

properties.description: The image-orientation CSS property specifies a layout-independent correction to the orientation of an image.

properties.name: image-rendering

values.name: auto
values.description: The scaling algorithm is UA dependent. Since version 1.9 (Firefox 3.0), Gecko uses bilinear resampling (high quality).

values.name: crisp-edges
values.description: The image is scaled with an algorithm that preserves contrast and edges in the image. Generally intended for images such as pixel art or line drawings, no blurring or color smoothing occurs.

values.name: -moz-crisp-edges
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: optimizeQuality
values.description: Deprecated.

values.name: optimizeSpeed
values.description: Deprecated.

values.name: pixelated
values.description: The image is scaled with the "nearest neighbor" or similar algorithm, preserving a "pixelated" look as the image changes in size.

values.name: smooth
values.description: The image should be scaled with an algorithm that maximizes the appearance of the image. In particular, scaling algorithms that "smooth" colors are acceptable, such as bilinear interpolation. This is intended for images such as photos.

values.name: high-quality
values.description: Identical to smooth, but with a preference for higher-quality scaling. If system resources are constrained, images with high-quality should be prioritized over those with any other value, when considering which images to degrade the quality of and to what degree.

properties.description: The image-rendering CSS property sets an image scaling algorithm. The property applies to an element itself, to any images set in its other properties, and to its descendants.

properties.name: image-resolution
properties.description: The image-resolution CSS property specifies the intrinsic resolution of all raster images used in or on the element. It affects content images such as replaced elements and generated content, and decorative images such as background-image images.

values.name: from-image
values.description: Uses the intrinsic resolution as specified by the image format. If the image does not specify its own resolution, the explicitly specified resolution is used (if given), else it defaults to 1dppx (1 image pixel per CSS px unit).

values.name: snap
values.description: If the snap keyword is provided, the computed resolution is the specified resolution rounded to the nearest value that would map one image pixel to an integer number of device pixels. If the resolution is taken from the image, then the used intrinsic resolution is the image's native resolution similarly adjusted.

properties.name: ime-mode

values.name: active
values.description: The input method editor is initially active; text entry is performed using it unless the user specifically dismisses it.

values.name: auto
values.description: No change is made to the current input method editor state. This is the default.

values.name: disabled
values.description: The input method editor is disabled and may not be activated by the user.

values.name: inactive
values.description: The input method editor is initially inactive, but the user may activate it if they wish.

values.name: normal
values.description: The IME state should be normal; this value can be used in a user style sheet to override the page setting.

properties.description: Controls the state of the input method editor for text fields.

properties.name: inherits

values.name: true
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: false
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: Specifies the inherit flag of the custom property registration represented by the @property rule, controlling whether or not the property inherits by default.

properties.name: initial-letter
properties.description: The initial-letter CSS property sets styling for dropped, raised, and sunken initial letters.

values.name: normal
values.description: No special initial-letter effect. Text behaves as normal.

properties.name: initial-letter-align
properties.description: The initial-letter-align CSS property specifies the alignment of initial letters within a paragraph.

values.name: auto
values.description: The user agent selects the value which corresponds to the language of the text. Western languages would default to alphabetic, CJK languages to ideographic, and some Indic languages to hanging.

values.name: alphabetic
values.description: As described above, the cap height of the initial letter aligns with the cap height of the first line of text. The baseline of the initial letter aligns with the baseline of the Nth text baseline.

values.name: hanging
values.description: The hanging baseline of the initial letter aligns with the hanging baseline of the first line of text.

values.name: ideographic
values.description: The initial letter is centered in the N-line area.

properties.name: initial-value
properties.description: Specifies the initial value of the custom property registration represented by the @property rule, controlling the property’s initial value.

properties.name: inline-size

values.name: auto
values.description: Depends on the values of other properties.

properties.description: The inline-size CSS property defines the horizontal or vertical size of an element's block, depending on its writing mode. It corresponds to either the width or the height property, depending on the value of writing-mode.

properties.name: input-security

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: none
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: Enables or disables the obscuring a sensitive test input.

properties.name: inset
properties.description: The inset CSS property is a shorthand that corresponds to the top, right, bottom, and/or left properties. It has the same multi-value syntax of the margin shorthand.

properties.name: inset-block
properties.description: The inset-block CSS property defines the logical block start and end offsets of an element, which maps to physical offsets depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top and bottom, or right and left properties depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.

properties.name: inset-block-end
properties.description: The inset-block-end CSS property defines the logical block end offset of an element, which maps to a physical inset depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top, right, bottom, or left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.

properties.name: inset-block-start
properties.description: The inset-block-start CSS property defines the logical block start offset of an element, which maps to a physical inset depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top, right, bottom, or left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.

properties.name: inset-inline
properties.description: The inset-inline CSS property defines the logical start and end offsets of an element in the inline direction, which maps to physical offsets depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top and bottom, or right and left properties depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.

properties.name: inset-inline-end
properties.description: The inset-inline-end CSS property defines the logical inline end inset of an element, which maps to a physical offset depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top, right, bottom, or left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.

properties.name: inset-inline-start
properties.description: The inset-inline-start CSS property defines the logical inline start inset of an element, which maps to a physical offset depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the top, right, bottom, or left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.

properties.name: isolation

values.name: auto
values.description: A new stacking context is created only if one of the properties applied to the element requires it.

values.name: isolate
values.description: A new stacking context must be created.

properties.description: The isolation CSS property determines whether an element must create a new stacking context.

properties.name: justify-items

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: normal
values.description:
The effect of this keyword is dependent of the layout mode we are in:
    
      In block-level layouts, the keyword is a synonym of start.
      In absolutely-positioned layouts, the keyword behaved like start on replaced absolutely-positioned boxes, and as stretch on all other absolutely-positioned boxes.
      In table cell layouts, this keyword has no meaning as this property is ignored.
      In flexbox layouts, this keyword has no meaning as this property is ignored.
      In grid layouts, this keyword leads to a behavior similar to the one of stretch, except for boxes with an aspect ratio or an intrinsic sizes where it behaves like start.

values.name: end
values.description: The item is packed flush to each other toward the end edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis.

values.name: start
values.description: The item is packed flush to each other toward the start edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis.

values.name: flex-end
values.description: For items that are not children of a flex container, this value is treated like end.

values.name: flex-start
values.description: For items that are not children of a flex container, this value is treated like start.

values.name: self-end
values.description: The item is packed flush to the edge of the alignment container of the end side of the item, in the appropriate axis.

values.name: self-start
values.description: The item is packed flush to the edge of the alignment container of the start side of the item, in the appropriate axis.

values.name: center
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the center of the alignment container.

values.name: left
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the left edge of the alignment container. If the property's axis is not parallel with the inline axis, this value behaves like start.

values.name: right
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the right edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis. If the property's axis is not parallel with the inline axis, this value behaves like start.

values.name: baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

values.name: first baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

values.name: last baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

values.name: stretch
values.description: If the combined size of the items is less than the size of the alignment container, any auto-sized items have their size increased equally (not proportionally), while still respecting the constraints imposed by max-height/max-width (or equivalent functionality), so that the combined size exactly fills the alignment container.

values.name: safe
values.description: If the size of the item overflows the alignment container, the item is instead aligned as if the alignment mode were start.

values.name: unsafe
values.description: Regardless of the relative sizes of the item and alignment container, the given alignment value is honored.

values.name: legacy
values.description: Makes the value inherited by the box descendants. Note that if a descendant has a justify-self: auto value, the legacy keyword is not considered by the descend, only the left, right, or center value associated to it.

values.name: baseline first baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box’s first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

properties.syntax: normal | stretch | <baseline-position> | <overflow-position>? [ <self-position> | left | right ] | legacy | legacy && [ left | right | center ]
properties.description: The CSS justify-items property defines the default justify-self for all items of the box, giving them all a default way of justifying each box along the appropriate axis.

properties.name: justify-self

values.name: auto
values.description: The value used is the value of the justify-items property of the parents box, unless the box has no parent, or is absolutely positioned, in these cases, auto represents normal.

values.name: normal

The effect of this keyword is dependent of the layout mode we are in:
    
      In block-level layouts, the keyword is a synonym of start.
      In absolutely-positioned layouts, the keyword behaves like start on replaced absolutely-positioned boxes, and as stretch on all other absolutely-positioned boxes.
      In table cell layouts, this keyword has no meaning as this property is ignored.
      In flexbox layouts, this keyword has no meaning as this property is ignored.
      In grid layouts, this keyword leads to a behavior similar to the one of stretch, except for boxes with an aspect ratio or an intrinsic sizes where it behaves like start.

properties.description: The CSS justify-self property sets the way a box is justified inside its alignment container along the appropriate axis.

properties.name: justify-tracks
properties.description: The justify-tracks CSS property sets the alignment in the masonry axis for grid containers that have masonry in their inline axis.

values.name: start
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the start edge of the alignment container in the masonry axis.

values.name: end
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the end edge of the alignment container in the masonry axis.

values.name: center
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the center of the alignment container along the masonry axis.

values.name: normal
values.description: Acts as start.

values.name: space-between
values.description: The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container along the masonry axis. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items is the same. The first item is flush with the main-start edge, and the last item is flush with the main-end edge.

values.name: space-around
values.description: The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container along the masonry axis. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items is the same. The empty space before the first and after the last item equals half of the space between each pair of adjacent items.

values.name: space-evenly
values.description: The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container along the masonry axis. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items, the main-start edge and the first item, and the main-end edge and the last item, are all exactly the same.

values.name: stretch
values.description: The items stretch along the masonry axis to fill the content box. Items with definite size do not stretch.

values.name: left
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the left edge of the alignment container.

values.name: right
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the right edge of the alignment container.

properties.name: kerning

values.name: auto
values.description: Indicates that the user agent should adjust inter-glyph spacing based on kerning tables that are included in the font that will be used.

properties.description: Indicates whether the user agent should adjust inter-glyph spacing based on kerning tables that are included in the relevant font or instead disable auto-kerning and set inter-character spacing to a specific length.

properties.name: lighting-color
properties.description: Defines the color of the light source for filter primitives 'feDiffuseLighting' and 'feSpecularLighting'.

properties.name: line-break

values.name: auto
values.description: Break text using the default line break rule.

values.name: loose
values.description: Break text using the least restrictive line break rule. Typically used for short lines, such as in newspapers.

values.name: normal
values.description: Break text using the most common line break rule.

values.name: strict
values.description: Break text using the most stringent line break rule.

values.name: anywhere
values.description: There is a soft wrap opportunity around every typographic character unit, including around any punctuation character or preserved white spaces, or in the middle of words, disregarding any prohibition against line breaks, even those introduced by characters with the GL, WJ, or ZWJ character class or mandated by the word-break property. The different wrapping opportunities must not be prioritized. Hyphenation is not applied.

properties.description: The line-break CSS property sets how to break lines of Chinese, Japanese, or Korean (CJK) text when working with punctuation and symbols.

properties.name: line-clamp
properties.description: The line-clamp property allows limiting the contents of a block container to the specified number of lines; remaining content is fragmented away and neither rendered nor measured. Optionally, it also allows inserting content into the last line box to indicate the continuity of truncated/interrupted content.

properties.name: line-gap-override
properties.description: Describes the line-gap metric of a font.

properties.name: line-height-step
properties.description: The line-height-step CSS property sets the step unit for line box heights. When the property is set, line box heights are rounded up to the closest multiple of the unit.

values.name: none
values.description: Specifies that no image is used as the marker. If this value is set, the marker defined in list-style-type will be used instead.

properties.description: The list-style-image CSS property sets an image to be used as the list item marker.

properties.description: Used to construct the default contents of a list item's marker

properties.name: margin-block
properties.description: The margin-block CSS shorthand property defines the logical block start and end margins of an element, which maps to physical margins depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: margin-block-end

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The margin-block-end CSS property defines the logical block end margin of an element, which maps to a physical margin depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: margin-block-start

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The margin-block-start CSS property defines the logical block start margin of an element, which maps to a physical margin depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: margin-inline
properties.description: The margin-inline CSS shorthand property is a shorthand property that defines both the logical inline start and end margins of an element, which maps to physical margins depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: margin-inline-end

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The margin-inline-end CSS property defines the logical inline end margin of an element, which maps to a physical margin depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. In other words, it corresponds to the margin-top, margin-right, margin-bottom or margin-left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.

properties.name: margin-inline-start

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The margin-inline-start CSS property defines the logical inline start margin of an element, which maps to a physical margin depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation. It corresponds to the margin-top, margin-right, margin-bottom, or margin-left property depending on the values defined for writing-mode, direction, and text-orientation.

properties.name: margin-trim

values.name: none
values.description: Margins are not trimmed by the container.

values.name: in-flow
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: all
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: block
values.description: Margins provided to the block children where they adjoin the container's edges are trimmed to zero without affecting the margins provided to the container.

values.name: block-start
values.description: Margin of the first block child with the container's edge is trimmed to zero.

values.name: block-end
values.description: Margin of last block child with the container's edge is trimmed to zero.

values.name: inline
values.description: Margins provided to the inline children where they adjoin the container's edges are trimmed to zero, without affecting the spacing at the beginning and end of the row.

values.name: inline-start
values.description: Margin between the container's edge and the first inline child is trimmed to zero.

values.name: inline-end
values.description: Margin between the container's edge and the last inline child is trimmed to zero.

properties.description: The margin-trim property allows the container to trim the margins of its children where they adjoin the container's edges.

properties.name: marker

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that no marker symbol will be drawn at the given vertex or vertices.

values.name: url()
values.description: Indicates that the <marker> element referenced will be used.

properties.description: Specifies the marker symbol that shall be used for all points on the sets the value for all vertices on the given 'path' element or basic shape.

properties.name: marker-end

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that no marker symbol will be drawn at the given vertex or vertices.

values.name: url()
values.description: Indicates that the <marker> element referenced will be used.

properties.description: Specifies the marker that will be drawn at the last vertices of the given markable element.

properties.name: marker-mid

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that no marker symbol will be drawn at the given vertex or vertices.

values.name: url()
values.description: Indicates that the <marker> element referenced will be used.

properties.description: Specifies the marker that will be drawn at all vertices except the first and last.

properties.name: marker-start

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that no marker symbol will be drawn at the given vertex or vertices.

values.name: url()
values.description: Indicates that the <marker> element referenced will be used.

properties.description: Specifies the marker that will be drawn at the first vertices of the given markable element.

properties.name: marks
properties.description: The marks CSS at-rule descriptor, used with the @page at-rule, adds crop and/or cross marks to the presentation of the document. Crop marks indicate where the page should be cut. Cross marks are used to align sheets.

properties.name: mask
properties.description: The mask CSS shorthand property hides an element (partially or fully) by masking or clipping the image at specific points.

properties.name: mask-border
properties.description: The mask-border CSS shorthand property lets you create a mask along the edge of an element's border.

properties.name: mask-border-mode

values.name: luminance
values.description: The luminance values of the mask border image are used as the mask values.

values.name: alpha
values.description: The alpha values of the mask border image are used as the mask values.

properties.description: The mask-border-mode CSS property specifies the blending mode used in a mask border.

properties.name: mask-border-outset
