properties.description: The mask-border-outset CSS property specifies the distance by which an element's mask border is set out from its border box.

properties.name: mask-border-repeat
properties.description: The mask-border-repeat CSS property sets how the edge regions of a source image are adjusted to fit the dimensions of an element's mask border.

values.name: stretch
values.description: The source image's edge regions are stretched to fill the gap between each border.

values.name: repeat
values.description: The source image's edge regions are tiled (repeated) to fill the gap between each border. Tiles may be clipped to achieve the proper fit.

values.name: round
values.description: The source image's edge regions are tiled (repeated) to fill the gap between each border. Tiles may be stretched to achieve the proper fit.

values.name: space
values.description: The source image's edge regions are tiled (repeated) to fill the gap between each border. Extra space will be distributed in between tiles to achieve the proper fit.

properties.name: mask-border-slice
properties.description: The mask-border-slice CSS property divides the image set by mask-border-source into regions. These regions are used to form the components of an element's mask border.

values.name: fill
values.description: Preserves the middle image region. Its width and height are sized to match the top and left image regions, respectively.

properties.name: mask-border-source
properties.description: The mask-border-source CSS property sets the source image used to create an element's mask border.

values.name: none
values.description: No mask border is used.

properties.name: mask-border-width
properties.description: The mask-border-width CSS property sets the width of an element's mask border.

values.name: auto
values.description: The width of the mask border is made equal to the intrinsic width or height (whichever is applicable) of the corresponding mask-border-slice. If the image does not have the required intrinsic dimension, the corresponding border-width is used instead.

properties.name: mask-clip
properties.description: The mask-clip CSS property determines the area which is affected by a mask. The painted content of an element must be restricted to this area.

values.name: content-box
values.description: The painted content is clipped to the content box.

values.name: padding-box
values.description: The painted content is clipped to the padding box.

values.name: border-box
values.description: The painted content is clipped to the border box.

values.name: fill-box
values.description: The painted content is clipped to the object bounding box.

values.name: stroke-box
values.description: The painted content is clipped to the stroke bounding box.

values.name: view-box
values.description: Uses the nearest SVG viewport as reference box. If a viewBox attribute is specified for the element creating the SVG viewport, the reference box is positioned at the origin of the coordinate system established by the viewBox attribute and the dimension of the reference box is set to the width and height values of the viewBox attribute.

values.name: no-clip
values.description: The painted content is not clipped.

values.name: border
values.description: This keyword behaves the same as border-box.

values.name: padding
values.description: This keyword behaves the same as padding-box.

values.name: content
values.description: This keyword behaves the same as content-box.

values.name: text
values.description: This keyword clips the mask image to the text of the element.

properties.name: mask-composite
properties.description: The mask-composite CSS property represents a compositing operation used on the current mask layer with the mask layers below it.

values.name: add
values.description: The source is placed over the destination.

values.name: subtract
values.description: The source is placed, where it falls outside of the destination.

values.name: intersect
values.description: The parts of source that overlap the destination, replace the destination.

values.name: exclude
values.description: The non-overlapping regions of source and destination are combined.

properties.name: mask-image

values.name: none
values.description: This keyword is interpreted as an opaque white image layer.

values.name: url()
values.description: Reference to a <mask element or to a CSS image.

properties.description:
The mask-image CSS property sets the image that is used as mask layer for an element.
  By default this means the alpha channel of the mask image will be multiplied with the alpha channel of the element. This can be controlled with the mask-mode property.

properties.name: mask-mode

values.name: alpha
values.description: This keyword indicates that the transparency (alpha channel) values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values.

values.name: auto
values.description: Use alpha values if 'mask-image' is an image, luminance if a <mask> element or a CSS image.

values.name: luminance
values.description: This keyword indicates that the luminance values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values.

values.name: match-source
values.description:
If the mask-image property is of type <mask-source>, the luminance values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values.
    If it is of type <image>, the alpha values of the mask layer image should be used as the mask values.

properties.description: The mask-mode CSS property sets whether the mask reference defined by mask-image is treated as a luminance or alpha mask.

properties.name: mask-origin
properties.description: The mask-origin CSS property sets the origin of a mask.

values.name: content-box
values.description: The position is relative to the content box.

values.name: padding-box
values.description: The position is relative to the padding box. For single boxes 0 0 is the upper left corner of the padding edge, 100% 100% is the lower right corner.

values.name: border-box
values.description: The position is relative to the border box.

values.name: fill-box
values.description: The position is relative to the object bounding box.

values.name: stroke-box
values.description: The position is relative to the stroke bounding box.

values.name: view-box
values.description: Uses the nearest SVG viewport as reference box. If a viewBox attribute is specified for the element creating the SVG viewport, the reference box is positioned at the origin of the coordinate system established by the viewBox attribute and the dimension of the reference box is set to the width and height values of the viewBox attribute.

values.name: content
values.description: Same as content-box.

values.name: padding
values.description: Same as padding-box.

values.name: border
values.description: Same as border-box.

properties.name: mask-position
properties.description: The mask-position CSS property sets the initial position, relative to the mask position layer set by mask-origin, for each defined mask image.

properties.name: mask-repeat
properties.description: The mask-repeat CSS property sets how mask images are repeated. A mask image can be repeated along the horizontal axis, the vertical axis, both axes, or not repeated at all.

properties.name: mask-size

values.name: auto
values.description: If the image has an intrinsic proportion, then render it using the specified dimension and compute the other dimension from the specified dimension and the intrinsic proportion. If the image has no intrinsic proportion, use the specified dimension for that dimension. For the other dimension, use the image's corresponding intrinsic dimension if there is one. If there is no such intrinsic dimension, use the corresponding dimension of the mask positioning area.

values.name: contain
values.description: The image is rendered by preserving its intrinsic proportion at the largest size contained within or covering the mask positioning area. If the image has no intrinsic proportion, then it is rendered at the size of the mask positioning area.

values.name: cover
values.description: The image is rendered by preserving its intrinsic proportion at the largest size contained within or covering the mask positioning area. If the image has no intrinsic proportion, then it is rendered at the size of the mask positioning area.

values.name: mask-size
values.description: If the image has an intrinsic proportion, then render it using the specified dimension and compute the other dimension from the specified dimension and the intrinsic proportion. If the image has no intrinsic proportion, use the specified dimension for that dimension. For the other dimension, use the image's corresponding intrinsic dimension if there is one. If there is no such intrinsic dimension, use the corresponding dimension of the mask positioning area.

values.name: auto auto
values.description: If the image has both intrinsic dimensions, it is rendered at that size. If it has no intrinsic dimensions and no intrinsic proportion, it is rendered at the size of the mask positioning area. If it has no dimensions but has a proportion, it's rendered as if contain had been specified instead. If the image has one intrinsic dimension and a proportion, it's rendered at the size determined by that one dimension and the proportion. If the image has one intrinsic dimension but no proportion, it's rendered using the intrinsic dimension and the corresponding dimension of the mask positioning area.

properties.description: The mask-size CSS property specifies the sizes of the mask images. The size of the image can be fully or partially constrained in order to preserve its intrinsic ratio.

properties.name: mask-type

values.name: alpha
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the associated mask image is an alpha mask, i.e., that its alpha channel values must be used when applying it.

values.name: luminance
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the associated mask image is a luminance mask, i.e., that its relative luminance values must be used when applying it.

properties.description: The mask-type CSS property sets whether an SVG <mask> element is used as a luminance or an alpha mask. It applies to the <mask> element itself.

properties.name: masonry-auto-flow
properties.description: The masonry-auto-flow CSS property modifies how items are placed when using masonry in CSS Grid Layout.

values.name: pack
values.description: As per the default masonry algorithm, items will be placed into the track with the most room.

values.name: next
values.description: Items will be placed one after the other in the grid axis.

values.name: definite-first
values.description: Display as in the default masonry algorithm, placing items with a definite place first before placing other masonry items.

values.name: ordered
values.description: Ignore any items with a definite placement, and place everything according to order-modified document order.

properties.name: math-depth
properties.description: The math-depth property describes a notion of depth for each element of a mathematical formula, with respect to the top-level container of that formula. This is used to scale the computed value of the font-size of elements when font-size: math is applied.

values.name: auto-add
values.description: Set to the inherited math-depth plus 1 when inherited math-style is compact.

values.name: add(<integer>)
values.description: Set to the inherited math-depth plus the specified integer.

properties.name: math-shift

values.name: normal
values.description: The initial value, indicates normal rendering. Superscripts in MathML formulas use the superscriptShiftUp parameter from the OpenType MATH table.

values.name: compact
values.description: Indicates compact rendering. Superscripts in MathML formulas use the superscriptShiftUpCramped parameter from the OpenType MATH table, which is generally smaller.

properties.description: The math-shift property indicates whether superscripts inside MathML formulas should be raised by a normal or compact shift.

properties.name: math-style

values.name: normal
values.description: The initial value, indicates normal rendering.

values.name: compact
values.description: The math layout on descendants tries to minimize the logical height.

properties.description: The math-style property indicates whether MathML equations should render with normal or compact height.

properties.name: max-block-size

values.name: none
values.description: No limit on the size of the box.

values.name: max-content
values.description: The intrinsic preferred max-block-size.

values.name: min-content
values.description: The intrinsic minimum max-block-size.

values.name: fit-content(<length-percentage>)
values.description: Uses the fit-content formula with the available space replaced by the specified argument, i.e. min(max-content, max(min-content, argument)).

properties.description: The max-block-size CSS property specifies the maximum size of an element in the direction opposite that of the writing direction as specified by writing-mode. That is, if the writing direction is horizontal, then max-block-size is equivalent to max-height; if the writing direction is vertical, max-block-size is the same as max-width.

properties.name: max-inline-size

values.name: none
values.description: No limit on the height of the box.

properties.description: The max-inline-size CSS property defines the horizontal or vertical maximum size of an element's block, depending on its writing mode. It corresponds to either the max-width or the max-height property, depending on the value of writing-mode.

properties.name: max-lines
properties.description: The max-lines property forces a break after a set number of lines

properties.name: max-zoom
properties.description:
The max-zoom CSS descriptor sets the maximum zoom factor of a document defined by the @viewport at-rule. The browser will not zoom in any further than this, whether automatically or at the user's request.

A zoom factor of 1.0 or 100% corresponds to no zooming. Larger values are zoomed in. Smaller values are zoomed out.

properties.name: min-block-size
properties.description: The min-block-size CSS property defines the minimum horizontal or vertical size of an element's block, depending on its writing mode. It corresponds to either the min-width or the min-height property, depending on the value of writing-mode.

properties.name: min-inline-size
properties.description: The min-inline-size CSS property defines the horizontal or vertical minimal size of an element's block, depending on its writing mode. It corresponds to either the min-width or the min-height property, depending on the value of writing-mode.

properties.name: min-zoom
properties.description:
The min-zoom CSS descriptor sets the minimum zoom factor of a document defined by the @viewport at-rule. The browser will not zoom out any further than this, whether automatically or at the user's request.

A zoom factor of 1.0 or 100% corresponds to no zooming. Larger values are zoomed in. Smaller values are zoomed out.

properties.name: mix-blend-mode

values.name: normal
values.description: Default attribute which specifies no blending

values.name: multiply
values.description: The source color is multiplied by the destination color and replaces the destination.

values.name: screen
values.description: Multiplies the complements of the backdrop and source color values, then complements the result.

values.name: overlay
values.description: Multiplies or screens the colors, depending on the backdrop color value.

values.name: darken
values.description: Selects the darker of the backdrop and source colors.

values.name: lighten
values.description: Selects the lighter of the backdrop and source colors.

values.name: color-dodge
values.description: Brightens the backdrop color to reflect the source color.

values.name: color-burn
values.description: Darkens the backdrop color to reflect the source color.

values.name: hard-light
values.description: Multiplies or screens the colors, depending on the source color value.

values.name: soft-light
values.description: Darkens or lightens the colors, depending on the source color value.

values.name: difference
values.description: Subtracts the darker of the two constituent colors from the lighter color..

values.name: exclusion
values.description: Produces an effect similar to that of the Difference mode but lower in contrast.

values.name: hue
values.description: Creates a color with the hue of the source color and the saturation and luminosity of the backdrop color.

values.name: saturation
values.description: Creates a color with the saturation of the source color and the hue and luminosity of the backdrop color.

values.name: color
values.description: Creates a color with the hue and saturation of the source color and the luminosity of the backdrop color.

values.name: luminosity
values.description: Creates a color with the luminosity of the source color and the hue and saturation of the backdrop color.

properties.description: The mix-blend-mode CSS property sets how an element's content should blend with the content of the element's parent and the element's background.

properties.name: motion

values.name: none
values.description: No motion path gets created.

values.name: path()
values.description: Defines an SVG path as a string, with optional 'fill-rule' as the first argument.

values.name: auto
values.description: Indicates that the object is rotated by the angle of the direction of the motion path.

values.name: reverse
values.description: Indicates that the object is rotated by the angle of the direction of the motion path plus 180 degrees.

properties.description: Shorthand property for setting 'motion-path', 'motion-offset' and 'motion-rotation'.

properties.name: motion-offset
properties.description: A distance that describes the position along the specified motion path.

properties.name: motion-path

values.name: none
values.description: No motion path gets created.

values.name: path()
values.description: Defines an SVG path as a string, with optional 'fill-rule' as the first argument.

properties.description: Specifies the motion path the element gets positioned at.

properties.name: motion-rotation

values.name: auto
values.description: Indicates that the object is rotated by the angle of the direction of the motion path.

values.name: reverse
values.description: Indicates that the object is rotated by the angle of the direction of the motion path plus 180 degrees.

properties.description: Defines the direction of the element while positioning along the motion path.

properties.name: nav-down

values.name: auto
values.description: The user agent automatically determines which element to navigate the focus to in response to directional navigational input.

values.name: current
values.description: Indicates that the user agent should target the frame that the element is in.

values.name: root
values.description: Indicates that the user agent should target the full window.

properties.description: Provides an way to control directional focus navigation.

properties.name: nav-index

values.name: auto
values.description: The element's sequential navigation order is assigned automatically by the user agent.

properties.description: Provides an input-method-neutral way of specifying the sequential navigation order (also known as 'tabbing order').

properties.name: nav-left

values.name: auto
values.description: The user agent automatically determines which element to navigate the focus to in response to directional navigational input.

values.name: current
values.description: Indicates that the user agent should target the frame that the element is in.

values.name: root
values.description: Indicates that the user agent should target the full window.

properties.description: Provides an way to control directional focus navigation.

properties.name: nav-right

values.name: auto
values.description: The user agent automatically determines which element to navigate the focus to in response to directional navigational input.

values.name: current
values.description: Indicates that the user agent should target the frame that the element is in.

values.name: root
values.description: Indicates that the user agent should target the full window.

properties.description: Provides an way to control directional focus navigation.

properties.name: nav-up

values.name: auto
values.description: The user agent automatically determines which element to navigate the focus to in response to directional navigational input.

values.name: current
values.description: Indicates that the user agent should target the frame that the element is in.

values.name: root
values.description: Indicates that the user agent should target the full window.

properties.description: Provides an way to control directional focus navigation.

properties.name: negative
properties.description: @counter-style descriptor. Defines how to alter the representation when the counter value is negative.

properties.name: object-fit

values.name: contain
values.description: The replaced content is scaled to maintain its aspect ratio while fitting within the element's content box. The entire object is made to fill the box, while preserving its aspect ratio, so the object will be "letterboxed" if its aspect ratio does not match the aspect ratio of the box.

values.name: cover
values.description: The replaced content is sized to maintain its aspect ratio while filling the element's entire content box. If the object's aspect ratio does not match the aspect ratio of its box, then the object will be clipped to fit.

values.name: fill
values.description: The replaced content is sized to fill the element's content box. The entire object will completely fill the box. If the object's aspect ratio does not match the aspect ratio of its box, then the object will be stretched to fit.

values.name: none
values.description: The replaced content is not resized.

values.name: scale-down
values.description: The content is sized as if none or contain were specified, whichever would result in a smaller concrete object size.

properties.description: The object-fit CSS property sets how the content of a replaced element, such as an or

properties.name: object-position
properties.description: The object-position CSS property specifies the alignment of the selected replaced element's contents within the element's box. Areas of the box which aren't covered by the replaced element's object will show the element's background.

properties.name: offset
properties.description: The offset CSS shorthand property sets all the properties required for animating an element along a defined path. The offset properties together help to define an offset transform, a transform that aligns a point in an element (offset-anchor) to an offset position (offset-position) on a path (offset-path) at various points along the path (offset-distance) and optionally rotates the element (offset-rotate) to follow the direction of the path.

properties.name: offset-anchor
properties.description: The offset-anchor CSS property specifies the point inside the box of an element traveling along an offset-path that is actually moving along the path.

values.name: auto
values.description: offset-anchor is given the same value as the element's transform-origin, unless offset-path is none, in which case it takes its value from offset-position.

properties.name: offset-block-end

values.name: auto
values.description: For non-replaced elements, the effect of this value depends on which of related properties have the value 'auto' as well.

properties.description: Logical 'bottom'. Mapping depends on the parent element's 'writing-mode', 'direction', and 'text-orientation'.

properties.name: offset-block-start

values.name: auto
values.description: For non-replaced elements, the effect of this value depends on which of related properties have the value 'auto' as well.

properties.description: Logical 'top'. Mapping depends on the parent element's 'writing-mode', 'direction', and 'text-orientation'.

properties.name: offset-distance
properties.description: The offset-distance CSS property specifies a position along an offset-path for an element to be placed.

properties.name: offset-inline-end

values.name: auto
values.description: For non-replaced elements, the effect of this value depends on which of related properties have the value 'auto' as well.

properties.description: Logical 'right'. Mapping depends on the parent element's 'writing-mode', 'direction', and 'text-orientation'.

properties.name: offset-inline-start

values.name: auto
values.description: For non-replaced elements, the effect of this value depends on which of related properties have the value 'auto' as well.

properties.description: Logical 'left'. Mapping depends on the parent element's 'writing-mode', 'direction', and 'text-orientation'.

properties.name: offset-path
properties.description: The offset-path CSS property specifies a path for an element to follow and determines the element's positioning within the path's parent container or the SVG coordinate system. The path is a line, a curve, or a geometrical shape along which the element gets positioned or moves.

values.name: none
values.description: Specifies that the element does not follow any offset path. The none value is equivalent to the element not having any offset transform. The element's movement in this case is determined by its default position properties, such as top and left, instead of an offset path. This is the default value.

values.name: ray()
values.description: Defines a line starting at a set position, of a set length, and extending at the specified angle. The ray() function accepts up to four parameters – an <angle>, an optional size value, the optional keyword contain, and an optional at <position>.

properties.name: offset-position
properties.description: The offset-position CSS property defines the initial position of an element along a path. This property is typically used in combination with the offset-path property to create a motion effect. The value of offset-position determines where the element gets placed initially for moving along an offset-path if the offset-path function does not specify its own starting position.

values.name: normal
values.description: Indicates that the element does not have an offset starting position and places the element at (50%, 50%) of the containing block

values.name: auto
values.description: Indicates that the offset starting position is the top-left corner of the element's box. This is the default value.

properties.name: offset-rotate
properties.description: The offset-rotate CSS property defines the orientation/direction of the element as it is positioned along the offset-path.

properties.name: order
properties.description: The order CSS property sets the order to lay out an item in a flex or grid container. Items in a container are sorted by ascending order value and then by their source code order.

properties.name: orientation

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: portrait
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: landscape
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The orientation CSS @media media feature can be used to apply styles based on the orientation of the viewport (or the page box, for paged media).

properties.name: orphans
properties.description: The orphans CSS property sets the minimum number of lines in a block container that must be shown at the bottom of a page, region, or column.

properties.name: outline

values.name: auto
values.description: Permits the user agent to render a custom outline style, typically the default platform style.

values.name: invert
values.description: Performs a color inversion on the pixels on the screen.

properties.description: The outline CSS shorthand property sets most of the outline properties in a single declaration.

properties.name: outline-color

values.name: invert
values.description: To ensure the outline is visible, performs a color inversion of the background. Note that browsers are not required to support this value; if they don't, this keyword is considered invalid.

properties.description: The outline-color CSS property sets the color of an element's outline.

properties.name: outline-offset
properties.description: The outline-offset CSS property sets the amount of space between an outline and the edge or border of an element.

properties.name: outline-style

values.name: auto
values.description: Permits the user agent to render a custom outline style.

values.name: none
values.description: No outline is used. The outline-width is 0.

values.name: dotted
values.description: The outline is a series of dots.

values.name: dashed
values.description: The outline is a series of short line segments.

values.name: solid
values.description: The outline is a single line.

values.name: double
values.description: The outline is two single lines. The outline-width is the sum of the two lines and the space between them.

values.name: groove
values.description: The outline looks as though it were carved into the page.

values.name: ridge
values.description: The opposite of groove: the outline looks as though it were extruded from the page.

values.name: inset
values.description: The outline makes the box look as though it were embedded in the page.

values.name: outset
values.description: The opposite of inset: the outline makes the box look as though it were coming out of the page.

properties.description: The outline-style CSS property sets the style of an element's outline. An outline is a line that is drawn around an element, outside the border.

properties.name: outline-width
properties.description: The CSS outline-width property sets the thickness of an element's outline. An outline is a line that is drawn around an element, outside the border.

values.name: thin
values.description: Depends on the user agent. Typically equivalent to 1px in desktop browsers (including Firefox).

values.name: medium
values.description: Depends on the user agent. Typically equivalent to 3px in desktop browsers (including Firefox).

values.name: thick
values.description: Depends on the user agent. Typically equivalent to 5px in desktop browsers (including Firefox).

properties.name: overflow-anchor

values.name: auto
values.description: The element becomes a potential anchor when adjusting scroll position.

values.name: none
values.description: The element won't be selected as a potential anchor.

properties.description: The overflow-anchor CSS property provides a way to opt out of the browser's scroll anchoring behavior, which adjusts scroll position to minimize content shifts.

properties.name: overflow-block

values.name: visible
values.description: Content is not clipped and may be rendered outside the padding box's block start and block end edges.

values.name: hidden
values.description: Content is clipped if necessary to fit the block dimension in the padding box. No scrollbars are provided.

values.name: clip
values.description: Overflow content is clipped at the element's overflow clip edge that is defined using the overflow-clip-margin property.

values.name: scroll
values.description: Content is clipped if necessary to fit in the block dimension in the padding box. Browsers display scrollbars whether or not any content is actually clipped. (This prevents scrollbars from appearing or disappearing when the content changes.) Printers may still print overflowing content.

values.name: auto
values.description: Depends on the user agent. If content fits inside the padding box, it looks the same as visible, but still establishes a new block-formatting context.

properties.description: The overflow-block CSS property sets what shows when content overflows the block start and block end edges of a box. This may be nothing, a scroll bar, or the overflow content.

properties.name: overflow-clip-box

values.name: padding-box
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: content-box
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The overflow-clip-box CSS property specifies relative to which box the clipping happens when there is an overflow. It is short hand for the overflow-clip-box-inline and overflow-clip-box-block properties.

properties.name: overflow-clip-margin
properties.description: The overflow-clip-margin CSS property determines how far outside its bounds an element with overflow: clip may be painted before being clipped. The bound defined by this property is called the overflow clip edge of the box.

properties.name: overflow-inline

values.name: visible
values.description: Content is not clipped and may be rendered outside the padding box's inline start and end edges.

values.name: hidden
values.description: Content is clipped if necessary to fit the inline dimension in the padding box. No scrollbars are provided.

values.name: clip
values.description: Overflow content is clipped at the element's overflow clip edge that is defined using the overflow-clip-margin property.

values.name: scroll
values.description: Content is clipped if necessary to fit in the padding box in the inline dimension. Browsers display scrollbars whether or not any content is actually clipped. (This prevents scrollbars from appearing or disappearing when the content changes.) Printers may still print overflowing content.

values.name: auto
values.description: Depends on the user agent. If content fits inside the padding box, it looks the same as visible, but still establishes a new block-formatting context. Desktop browsers provide scrollbars if content overflows.

properties.description: The overflow-inline CSS property sets what shows when content overflows the inline start and end edges of a box. This may be nothing, a scroll bar, or the overflow content.

properties.name: overflow-wrap

values.name: break-word
values.description: The same as the anywhere value, with normally unbreakable words allowed to be broken at arbitrary points if there are no otherwise acceptable break points in the line, but soft wrap opportunities introduced by the word break are NOT considered when calculating min-content intrinsic sizes.

values.name: normal
values.description: Lines may only break at normal word break points (such as a space between two words).

values.name: anywhere
values.description: To prevent overflow, an otherwise unbreakable string of characters — like a long word or URL — may be broken at any point if there are no otherwise-acceptable break points in the line. No hyphenation character is inserted at the break point. Soft wrap opportunities introduced by the word break are considered when calculating min-content intrinsic sizes.

properties.description: The overflow-wrap CSS property applies to inline elements, setting whether the browser should insert line breaks within an otherwise unbreakable string to prevent text from overflowing its line box.

properties.name: overflow-x

values.name: auto
values.description:
Overflow content is clipped at the element's padding box, and overflow content can be scrolled into view. Unlike scroll, user agents display scroll bars only if the content is overflowing and hide scroll bars by default. If content fits inside the element's padding box, it looks the same as with visible, but still establishes a new block-formatting context. Desktop browsers provide scroll bars if content overflows.
    
      Note: The keyword value overlay is a legacy value alias for auto. With overlay, the scroll bars are drawn on top of the content instead of taking up space.

values.name: hidden
values.description: Overflow content is clipped if necessary to fit horizontally in the elements' padding box. No scroll bars are provided.

values.name: scroll
values.description: Overflow content is clipped if necessary to fit horizontally inside the element's padding box. Browsers display scroll bars in the horizontal direction whether or not any content is actually clipped. (This prevents scroll bars from appearing or disappearing when the content changes.) Printers may still print overflowing content.

values.name: visible
values.description: Overflow content is not clipped and may be visible outside the element's padding box on left and right edges. The element box is not a scroll container.

values.name: clip
values.description: Overflow content is clipped at the element's overflow clip edge that is defined using the overflow-clip-margin property. As a result, content overflows the element's padding box by the <length> value of overflow-clip-margin or by 0px if not set. The difference between clip and hidden is that the clip keyword also forbids all scrolling, including programmatic scrolling. No new formatting context is created. To establish a formatting context, use overflow: clip along with display: flow-root. The element box is not a scroll container.

properties.description: The overflow-x CSS property sets what shows when content overflows a block-level element's left and right edges. This may be nothing, a scroll bar, or the overflow content. This property may also be set by using the overflow shorthand property.

properties.name: overflow-y

values.name: auto
values.description: Overflow content is clipped at the element's padding box, and overflow content can be scrolled into view. Unlike scroll, user agents display scroll bars only if the content is overflowing, hiding scroll bars by default. If content fits inside the element's padding box, it looks the same as with visible, but still establishes a new block-formatting context.

values.name: hidden
values.description: Overflow content is clipped if necessary to fit vertically in the elements' padding box. No scroll bars are provided.

values.name: scroll
values.description: Overflow content is clipped if necessary to fit vertically inside the element's padding box. Browsers display scroll bars in the vertical direction whether or not any content is actually clipped. (This prevents scroll bars from appearing or disappearing when the content changes.) Printers may still print overflowing content.

values.name: visible
values.description: Overflow content is not clipped and may be visible outside the element's padding box at the top and bottom edges. The element box is not a scroll container.

values.name: clip
values.description: Overflow content is clipped at the element's overflow clip edge that is defined using the overflow-clip-margin property. As a result, content overflows the element's padding box by the <length> value of overflow-clip-margin or by 0px if not set. The difference between clip and hidden is that the clip keyword also forbids all scrolling, including programmatic scrolling. No new formatting context is created. To establish a formatting context, use overflow: clip along with display: flow-root. The element box is not a scroll container.

properties.description: The overflow-y CSS property sets what shows when content overflows a block-level element's top and bottom edges. This may be nothing, a scroll bar, or the overflow content. This property may also be set by using the overflow shorthand property.

properties.name: override-colors
properties.description: The override-colors CSS descriptor is used to override colors in the chosen base-palette for a color font.

properties.name: overscroll-behavior
properties.description: The overscroll-behavior CSS property sets what a browser does when reaching the boundary of a scrolling area.

values.name: auto
values.description: The default scroll overflow behavior occurs as normal.

values.name: contain
values.description: Default scroll overflow behavior (e.g., "bounce" effects) is observed inside the element where this value is set. However, no scroll chaining occurs on neighboring scrolling areas; the underlying elements will not scroll. The contain value disables native browser navigation, including the vertical pull-to-refresh gesture and horizontal swipe navigation.

values.name: none
values.description: No scroll chaining occurs to neighboring scrolling areas, and default scroll overflow behavior is prevented.

properties.name: overscroll-behavior-block

values.name: contain
values.description: Default scroll overflow behavior (e.g., "bounce" effects) is observed inside the element where this value is set. However, no scroll chaining occurs on neighboring scrolling areas; the underlying elements will not scroll. The contain value disables native browser navigation, including the vertical pull-to-refresh gesture and horizontal swipe navigation.

values.name: none
values.description: No scroll chaining occurs to neighboring scrolling areas, and default scroll overflow behavior is prevented.

values.name: auto
values.description: The default scroll overflow behavior occurs as normal.

properties.description: The overscroll-behavior-block CSS property sets the browser's behavior when the block direction boundary of a scrolling area is reached.

properties.name: overscroll-behavior-inline

values.name: contain
values.description: Default scroll overflow behavior (e.g., "bounce" effects) is observed inside the element where this value is set. However, no scroll chaining occurs on neighboring scrolling areas; the underlying elements will not scroll. The contain value disables native browser navigation, including the vertical pull-to-refresh gesture and horizontal swipe navigation.

values.name: none
values.description: No scroll chaining occurs to neighboring scrolling areas, and default scroll overflow behavior is prevented.

values.name: auto
values.description: The default scroll overflow behavior occurs as normal.

properties.description: The overscroll-behavior-inline CSS property sets the browser's behavior when the inline direction boundary of a scrolling area is reached.

properties.name: overscroll-behavior-x

values.name: contain
values.description: Default scroll overflow behavior (e.g., "bounce" effects) is observed inside the element where this value is set. However, no scroll chaining occurs on neighboring scrolling areas; the underlying elements will not scroll. The contain value disables native browser navigation, including the vertical pull-to-refresh gesture and horizontal swipe navigation.

values.name: none
values.description: No scroll chaining occurs to neighboring scrolling areas, and default scroll overflow behavior is prevented.

values.name: auto
values.description: The default scroll overflow behavior occurs as normal.

properties.description: The overscroll-behavior-x CSS property sets the browser's behavior when the horizontal boundary of a scrolling area is reached.

properties.name: overscroll-behavior-y

values.name: contain
values.description: Default scroll overflow behavior (e.g., "bounce" effects) is observed inside the element where this value is set. However, no scroll chaining occurs on neighboring scrolling areas; the underlying elements will not scroll. The contain value disables native browser navigation, including the vertical pull-to-refresh gesture and horizontal swipe navigation.

values.name: none
values.description: No scroll chaining occurs to neighboring scrolling areas, and default scroll overflow behavior is prevented.

values.name: auto
values.description: The default scroll overflow behavior occurs as normal.

properties.description: The overscroll-behavior-y CSS property sets the browser's behavior when the vertical boundary of a scrolling area is reached.

properties.name: pad
properties.description: @counter-style descriptor. Specifies a "fixed-width" counter style, where representations shorter than the pad value are padded with a particular <symbol>

properties.name: padding-block
properties.description: The padding-block CSS shorthand property defines the logical block start and end padding of an element, which maps to physical padding properties depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: padding-block-end
properties.description: The padding-block-end CSS property defines the logical block end padding of an element, which maps to a physical padding depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: padding-block-start
properties.description: The padding-block-start CSS property defines the logical block start padding of an element, which maps to a physical padding depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: padding-inline
properties.description: The padding-inline CSS shorthand property defines the logical inline start and end padding of an element, which maps to physical padding properties depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: padding-inline-end
properties.description: The padding-inline-end CSS property defines the logical inline end padding of an element, which maps to a physical padding depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: padding-inline-start
properties.description: The padding-inline-start CSS property defines the logical inline start padding of an element, which maps to a physical padding depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: page
properties.description: The page CSS property is used to specify the named page, a specific type of page defined by the @page at-rule.

values.name: auto
values.description: Default value. Use the value of the nearest ancestor with a non-auto value. If no ancestor has a named page value set, the used value for auto is the empty string.

properties.name: page-break-after

values.name: always
values.description: Always force page breaks after the element.

values.name: auto
values.description: Initial value. Automatic page breaks (neither forced nor forbidden).

values.name: avoid
values.description: Avoid page breaks after the element.

values.name: left
values.description: Force page breaks after the element so that the next page is formatted as a left page. It's the page placed on the left side of the spine of the book or the back side of the page in duplex printing.

values.name: right
values.description: Force page breaks after the element so that the next page is formatted as a right page. It's the page placed on the right side of the spine of the book or the front side of the page in duplex printing.

values.name: recto
values.description: If pages progress left-to-right, then this acts like right. If pages progress right-to-left, then this acts like left.

values.name: verso
values.description: If pages progress left-to-right, then this acts like left. If pages progress right-to-left, then this acts like right.

properties.syntax: auto | always | avoid | left | right | recto | verso
properties.description: The page-break-after CSS property adjusts page breaks after the current element.

properties.name: page-break-before

values.name: always
values.description: Always force page breaks before the element.

values.name: auto
values.description: Initial value. Automatic page breaks (neither forced nor forbidden).

values.name: avoid
values.description: Avoid page breaks before the element.

values.name: left
values.description: Force page breaks before the element so that the next page is formatted as a left page. It's the page placed on the left side of the spine of the book or the back side of the page in duplex printing.

values.name: right
values.description: Force page breaks before the element so that the next page is formatted as a right page. It's the page placed on the right side of the spine of the book or the front side of the page in duplex printing.

values.name: recto
values.description: If pages progress left-to-right, then this acts like right. If pages progress right-to-left, then this acts like left.

values.name: verso
values.description: If pages progress left-to-right, then this acts like left. If pages progress right-to-left, then this acts like right.

properties.syntax: auto | always | avoid | left | right | recto | verso
properties.description: The page-break-before CSS property adjusts page breaks before the current element.

properties.name: page-break-inside

values.name: auto
values.description: Initial value. Automatic page breaks (neither forced nor forbidden).

values.name: avoid
values.description: Avoid page breaks inside the element.

properties.description: The page-break-inside CSS property adjusts page breaks inside the current element.

properties.name: page-orientation
properties.description: The page-orientation CSS descriptor for the @page at-rule controls the rotation of a printed page. It handles the flow of content across pages when the orientation of a page is changed. This behavior differs from the size descriptor in that a user can define the direction in which to rotate the page.

properties.name: paint-order

values.name: fill
values.description: Specify some or all of these values in the order you want them to be painted in.

values.name: markers
values.description: Specify some or all of these values in the order you want them to be painted in.

values.name: normal
values.description: Paint the different items in normal paint order.

values.name: stroke
values.description: Specify some or all of these values in the order you want them to be painted in.

properties.description: The paint-order CSS property lets you control the order in which the fill and stroke (and painting markers) of text content and shapes are drawn.

properties.name: perspective

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that no perspective transform is to be applied.

properties.description: The perspective CSS property determines the distance between the z=0 plane and the user in order to give a 3D-positioned element some perspective.

properties.name: perspective-origin
properties.description: The perspective-origin CSS property determines the position at which the viewer is looking. It is used as the vanishing point by the perspective property.

properties.name: place-content
properties.description: The place-content CSS shorthand property allows you to align content along both the block and inline directions at once (i.e. the align-content and justify-content properties) in a relevant layout system such as Grid or Flexbox.

values.name: start
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the start edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis.

values.name: end
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the end edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis.

values.name: flex-start
values.description:
The items are packed flush to each other toward the edge of the alignment container depending on the flex container's main-start or cross-start side.
      This only applies to flex layout items. For items that are not children of a flex container, this value is treated like start.

values.name: flex-end
values.description:
The items are packed flush to each other toward the edge of the alignment container depending on the flex container's main-end or cross-end side.
      This only applies to flex layout items. For items that are not children of a flex container, this value is treated like end.

values.name: center
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the center of the alignment container.

values.name: left
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the left edge of the alignment container. If the property's axis is not parallel with the inline axis, this value behaves like start.

values.name: right
values.description: The items are packed flush to each other toward the right edge of the alignment container in the appropriate axis. If the property's axis is not parallel with the inline axis, this value behaves like start.

values.name: space-between
values.description: The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items is the same. The first item is flush with the main-start edge, and the last item is flush with the main-end edge.

values.name: baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

values.name: first baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

values.name: last baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

values.name: space-around
values.description: The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items is the same. The empty space before the first and after the last item equals half of the space between each pair of adjacent items.

values.name: space-evenly
values.description: The items are evenly distributed within the alignment container. The spacing between each pair of adjacent items, the main-start edge and the first item, and the main-end edge and the last item, are all exactly the same.

values.name: stretch
values.description: If the combined size of the items is less than the size of the alignment container, any auto-sized items have their size increased equally (not proportionally), while still respecting the constraints imposed by max-height/max-width (or equivalent functionality), so that the combined size exactly fills the alignment container

values.name: safe
values.description: Used alongside an alignment keyword. If the chosen keyword means that the item overflows the alignment container causing data loss, the item is instead aligned as if the alignment mode were start.

values.name: unsafe
values.description: Used alongside an alignment keyword. Regardless of the relative sizes of the item and alignment container, and regardless of whether overflow which causes data loss might happen, the given alignment value is honored.

values.name: baseline first baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box’s first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

properties.name: place-items
properties.description: The CSS place-items shorthand property allows you to align items along both the block and inline directions at once (i.e. the align-items and justify-items properties) in a relevant layout system such as Grid or Flexbox. If the second value is not set, the first value is also used for it.

values.name: auto
values.description: auto 实际的值继承父自元素的 justify-items 值，除非该元素没有父元素或是用了绝对定位。在这些示例中，auto 表示 normal 。

values.name: normal
values.description:
normal 的效果取决于我们使用哪种布局方式：
    
      在块级布局中，normal 和 start 一样。
      在绝对定位布局中，关键字在被替换的绝对定位元素上的行为类似于 start，在所有其他绝对定位的元素上表现类似 stretch。
      在表格单元格布局中，此关键字没有意义，因为该属性被忽略。
      在 flexbox 布局中，此关键字没有意义，因为该属性被忽略。
      在 grid 布局中，此关键字和 stretch 的行为相似，但是具有宽高比和固有尺寸的元素行为和 start 相似。

values.name: start
values.description: 在适当的轴线上，元素块沿着对齐容器的起始边缘对齐。

values.name: end
values.description: 在适当的轴线上，元素块沿着对齐容器的结束边缘对齐。

values.name: flex-start
values.description:
对齐方式取决于 flex 容器的的开始方向。（水平和垂直两个方向）
      这只对 flex 布局元素生效，对于不是 flex 容器的子元素，它被视为 start 。

values.name: flex-end
values.description:
对齐方式取决于 flex 容器的的结束方向。（水平和垂直两个方向）
      这只对 flex 布局元素生效，对于不是 flex 容器的子元素，它被视为 end。

values.name: self-start
values.description: 沿着轴线的头部对齐。

values.name: self-end
values.description: 沿着轴线的尾部对齐。

values.name: center
values.description: 沿着对齐容器的中心对齐。

values.name: left
values.description: 沿着对齐容器的左侧对齐，如果属性的轴不与内联轴平行，则该值的行为和 start 类似。

values.name: right
values.description: 沿着对齐容器的右侧对齐，如果属性的轴不与内联轴平行，则该值的行为和 start 类似。

values.name: baseline first baseline
values.description:
指定参与第一个或最后一个基线对齐：元素的第一个或最后一个基线集的对齐基线与基线共享组中所有框共享的第一个或最后一个基线集中相应的基线对齐。
      first baseline 的回退对齐方式为 start ，last baseline 则为 end。

values.name: last baseline
values.description:
指定参与第一个或最后一个基线对齐：元素的第一个或最后一个基线集的对齐基线与基线共享组中所有框共享的第一个或最后一个基线集中相应的基线对齐。
      first baseline 的回退对齐方式为 start ，last baseline 则为 end。

values.name: stretch
values.description: 如果子项加起来的尺寸小于对齐容器的尺寸，则任何未尺寸为 auto 的项将增加同等的大小（不是按比例），但也会受到 max-height/max-width （或等同的功能）的限制，因此所有项刚好能填满对齐容器。

properties.name: place-self
properties.description: The place-self CSS shorthand property allows you to align an individual item in both the block and inline directions at once (i.e. the align-self and justify-self properties) in a relevant layout system such as Grid or Flexbox. If the second value is not present, the first value is also used for it.

values.name: auto
values.description: Computes to the parent's align-items value.

values.name: normal
values.description:
The effect of this keyword is dependent of the layout mode we are in:
    
      In absolutely-positioned layouts, the keyword behaves like start on replaced absolutely-positioned boxes, and as stretch on all other absolutely-positioned boxes.
      In static position of absolutely-positioned layouts, the keyword behaves as stretch.
      For flex items, the keyword behaves as stretch.
      For grid items, this keyword leads to a behavior similar to the one of stretch, except for boxes with an aspect ratio or an intrinsic sizes where it behaves like start.
      The property doesn't apply to block-level boxes, and to table cells.

values.name: self-start
values.description: Aligns the items to be flush with the edge of the alignment container corresponding to the item's start side in the cross axis.

values.name: self-end
values.description: Aligns the items to be flush with the edge of the alignment container corresponding to the item's end side in the cross axis.

values.name: flex-start
values.description: The cross-start margin edge of the flex item is flushed with the cross-start edge of the line.

values.name: flex-end
values.description: The cross-end margin edge of the flex item is flushed with the cross-end edge of the line.

values.name: center
values.description: The flex item's margin box is centered within the line on the cross-axis. If the cross-size of the item is larger than the flex container, it will overflow equally in both directions.

values.name: baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

values.name: first baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

values.name: last baseline
values.description:
Specifies participation in first- or last-baseline alignment: aligns the alignment baseline of the box's first or last baseline set with the corresponding baseline in the shared first or last baseline set of all the boxes in its baseline-sharing group.
      The fallback alignment for first baseline is start, the one for last baseline is end.

values.name: stretch
values.description: If the combined size of the items along the cross axis is less than the size of the alignment container and the item is auto-sized, its size is increased equally (not proportionally), while still respecting the constraints imposed by max-height/max-width (or equivalent functionality), so that the combined size of all auto-sized items exactly fills the alignment container along the cross axis.

properties.name: prefix
properties.description: @counter-style descriptor. Specifies a <symbol> that is prepended to the marker representation.

properties.name: print-color-adjust

values.name: economy
values.description:
The user agent is allowed to make adjustments to the element as it deems appropriate and prudent in order to optimize the output for the device it's being rendered for.
      For example, when printing, a browser might opt to leave out all background images and to adjust text colors to be sure the contrast is optimized for reading on white paper.
      This is the default.

values.name: exact
values.description:
The element's content has been specifically and carefully crafted to use colors, images, and styles in a thoughtful and/or important way, such that being altered by the browser might actually make things worse rather than better.
      The appearance of the content should not be changed except by the user's request.
      For example, a page might include a list of information with rows whose background colors alternate between white and a light grey.
      Removing the background color would decrease the legibility of the content.

properties.description:
The print-color-adjust CSS property sets what, if anything, the user agent may do to optimize the appearance of the element on the output device.
  By default, the browser is allowed to make any adjustments to the element's appearance it determines to be necessary and prudent given the type and capabilities of the output device.

properties.name: quotes

values.name: none
values.description: The open-quote and close-quote values of the content property produce no quotation marks, as if no-open-quote and no-close-quote were set, respectively.

values.name: auto
values.description: Quotation marks that are typographically appropriate for the inherited language (i.e. via the lang attribute set on the parent or other ancestor).

values.name: [<string> <string>]+
values.description:
Defines one or more pairs of quotation mark values for opening and closing quotes. In each pair, the first of each pair of quotes are used as the values for the open-quote and the second of each pair is the close-quote.
    The first pair represents the quotation's outer level. The second pair, if present, represents the first nested level. The next pair is used for doubly nested levels, and so on. If the depth of quote nesting is greater than the number of pairs, the last pair in the quotes value is repeated.
    Which pair of quotes is used depends on the depth, or nesting level, of quotes: the number of occurrences of <q> quotes or open-quote (or no-open-quote) in all generated text before the current occurrence, minus the number of occurrences of closing quotes, either as </q>, close-quote, or no-close-quote. If the depth is 0, the first pair is used, if the depth is 1, the second pair is used, etc.

properties.description: The CSS quotes property sets how the browser should render quotation marks that are automatically added to the HTML <q> element or added using the open-quotes or close-quotes (or omitted using the no-open-quote and no-close-quote) values of the of the CSS content property.

properties.name: range

values.name: auto
values.description: The range depends on the counter system.

values.name: infinite
values.description: If used as the first value in a range, it represents negative infinity; if used as the second value, it represents positive infinity.

properties.description: @counter-style descriptor. Defines the ranges over which the counter style is defined.

properties.name: resize

values.name: both
values.description: The element displays a mechanism for allowing the user to resize it, which may be resized both horizontally and vertically.

values.name: horizontal
values.description: The element displays a mechanism for allowing the user to resize it in the horizontal direction.

values.name: none
values.description: The element offers no user-controllable method for resizing it.

values.name: vertical
values.description: The element displays a mechanism for allowing the user to resize it in the vertical direction.

values.name: block
values.description: The element displays a mechanism for allowing the user to resize it in the block direction (either horizontally or vertically, depending on the writing-mode and direction value).

values.name: inline
values.description: The element displays a mechanism for allowing the user to resize it in the inline direction (either horizontally or vertically, depending on the writing-mode and direction value).

properties.syntax: none | both | horizontal | vertical | block | inline
properties.description: The resize CSS property sets whether an element is resizable, and if so, in which directions.

properties.name: rotate
properties.description: The rotate CSS property allows you to specify rotation transforms individually and independently of the transform property. This maps better to typical user interface usage, and saves having to remember the exact order of transform functions to specify in the transform property.

values.name: none
values.description: Specifies that no rotation should be applied.

properties.name: row-gap
properties.description: The row-gap CSS property sets the size of the gap (gutter) between an element's rows.

properties.name: ruby-align

values.name: auto
values.description: The user agent determines how the ruby contents are aligned. This is the initial value.

values.name: center
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the ruby will be aligned at the middle of the base text.

values.name: distribute-letter
values.description: If the width of the ruby text is smaller than that of the base, then the ruby text contents are evenly distributed across the width of the base, with the first and last ruby text glyphs lining up with the corresponding first and last base glyphs. If the width of the ruby text is at least the width of the base, then the letters of the base are evenly distributed across the width of the ruby text.

values.name: distribute-space
values.description: If the width of the ruby text is smaller than that of the base, then the ruby text contents are evenly distributed across the width of the base, with a certain amount of white space preceding the first and following the last character in the ruby text. That amount of white space is normally equal to half the amount of inter-character space of the ruby text.

values.name: left
values.description: The ruby text content is aligned with the start edge of the base.

values.name: line-edge
values.description: If the ruby text is not adjacent to a line edge, it is aligned as in 'auto'. If it is adjacent to a line edge, then it is still aligned as in auto, but the side of the ruby text that touches the end of the line is lined up with the corresponding edge of the base.

values.name: right
values.description: The ruby text content is aligned with the end edge of the base.

values.name: start
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the ruby will be aligned with the start of the base text.

values.name: space-between
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the extra space will be distributed between the elements of the ruby.

values.name: space-around
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the extra space will be distributed between the elements of the ruby, and around it.

properties.description: The ruby-align CSS property defines the distribution of the different ruby elements over the base.

properties.name: ruby-merge

values.name: separate
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: collapse
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: This property controls how ruby annotation boxes should be rendered when there are more than one in a ruby container box: whether each pair should be kept separate, the annotations should be collapsed and rendered as a group, or the separation should be determined based on the space available.

properties.name: ruby-overhang

values.name: auto
values.description: The ruby text can overhang text adjacent to the base on either side. This is the initial value.

values.name: end
values.description: The ruby text can overhang the text that follows it.

values.name: none
values.description: The ruby text cannot overhang any text adjacent to its base, only its own base.

values.name: start
values.description: The ruby text can overhang the text that precedes it.

properties.description: Determines whether, and on which side, ruby text is allowed to partially overhang any adjacent text in addition to its own base, when the ruby text is wider than the ruby base.

properties.name: ruby-position

values.name: after
values.description: The ruby text appears after the base. This is a relatively rare setting used in ideographic East Asian writing systems, most easily found in educational text.

values.name: before
values.description: The ruby text appears before the base. This is the most common setting used in ideographic East Asian writing systems.

values.name: inline
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: right
values.description: The ruby text appears on the right of the base. Unlike 'before' and 'after', this value is not relative to the text flow direction.

values.name: over
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the ruby has to be placed over the main text for horizontal scripts and right to it for vertical scripts.

values.name: under
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the ruby has to be placed under the main text for horizontal scripts and left to it for vertical scripts.

values.name: inter-character
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the ruby has to be placed between the different characters.

values.name: alternate
values.description: Is a keyword indicating that the ruby alternates between over and under, when there are multiple levels of annotation.

properties.description: The ruby-position CSS property defines the position of a ruby element relatives to its base element. It can be positioned over the element (over), under it (under), or between the characters on their right side (inter-character).

properties.name: ruby-span

values.name: attr(x)
values.description: The value of attribute 'x' is a string value. The string value is evaluated as a <number> to determine the number of ruby base elements to be spanned by the annotation element.

values.name: none
values.description: No spanning. The computed value is '1'.

properties.description: Determines whether, and on which side, ruby text is allowed to partially overhang any adjacent text in addition to its own base, when the ruby text is wider than the ruby base.

properties.name: scale
properties.description: The scale CSS property allows you to specify scale transforms individually and independently of the transform property. This maps better to typical user interface usage, and saves having to remember the exact order of transform functions to specify in the transform value.

values.name: none
values.description: Specifies that no scaling should be applied.

properties.name: scroll-behavior

values.name: auto
values.description: The scrolling box scrolls instantly.

values.name: smooth
values.description: The scrolling box scrolls in a smooth fashion using a user-agent-defined easing function over a user-agent-defined period of time. User agents should follow platform conventions, if any.

properties.description: The scroll-behavior CSS property sets the behavior for a scrolling box when scrolling is triggered by the navigation or CSSOM scrolling APIs.

properties.name: scroll-margin
properties.description: The scroll-margin shorthand property sets all of the scroll margins of an element at once, assigning values much like the margin property does for margins of an element.

properties.name: scroll-margin-block
properties.description: The scroll-margin-block shorthand property sets the scroll margins of an element in the block dimension.

properties.name: scroll-margin-block-end
properties.description: The scroll-margin-block-end property defines the margin of the scroll snap area at the end of the block dimension that is used for snapping this box to the snapport. The scroll snap area is determined by taking the transformed border box, finding its rectangular bounding box (axis-aligned in the scroll container's coordinate space), then adding the specified outsets.

properties.name: scroll-margin-block-start
properties.description: The scroll-margin-block-start property defines the margin of the scroll snap area at the start of the block dimension that is used for snapping this box to the snapport. The scroll snap area is determined by taking the transformed border box, finding its rectangular bounding box (axis-aligned in the scroll container's coordinate space), then adding the specified outsets.

properties.name: scroll-margin-bottom
properties.description: The scroll-margin-bottom property defines the bottom margin of the scroll snap area that is used for snapping this box to the snapport. The scroll snap area is determined by taking the transformed border box, finding its rectangular bounding box (axis-aligned in the scroll container's coordinate space), then adding the specified outsets.

properties.name: scroll-margin-inline
properties.description: The scroll-margin-inline shorthand property sets the scroll margins of an element in the inline dimension.

properties.name: scroll-margin-inline-end
properties.description: The scroll-margin-inline-end property defines the margin of the scroll snap area at the end of the inline dimension that is used for snapping this box to the snapport. The scroll snap area is determined by taking the transformed border box, finding its rectangular bounding box (axis-aligned in the scroll container's coordinate space), then adding the specified outsets.

properties.name: scroll-margin-inline-start
properties.description: The scroll-margin-inline-start property defines the margin of the scroll snap area at the start of the inline dimension that is used for snapping this box to the snapport. The scroll snap area is determined by taking the transformed border box, finding its rectangular bounding box (axis-aligned in the scroll container's coordinate space), then adding the specified outsets.

properties.name: scroll-margin-left
properties.description: The scroll-margin-left property defines the left margin of the scroll snap area that is used for snapping this box to the snapport. The scroll snap area is determined by taking the transformed border box, finding its rectangular bounding box (axis-aligned in the scroll container's coordinate space), then adding the specified outsets.

properties.name: scroll-margin-right
properties.description: The scroll-margin-right property defines the right margin of the scroll snap area that is used for snapping this box to the snapport. The scroll snap area is determined by taking the transformed border box, finding its rectangular bounding box (axis-aligned in the scroll container's coordinate space), then adding the specified outsets.

properties.name: scroll-margin-top
properties.description: The scroll-margin-top property defines the top margin of the scroll snap area that is used for snapping this box to the snapport. The scroll snap area is determined by taking the transformed border box, finding its rectangular bounding box (axis-aligned in the scroll container's coordinate space), then adding the specified outsets.

properties.name: scroll-padding
properties.description: The scroll-padding shorthand property sets scroll padding on all sides of an element at once, much like the padding property does for padding on an element.

values.name: auto
values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but the user agent is free to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-padding-block
properties.description: The scroll-padding-block shorthand property sets the scroll padding of an element in the block dimension.

values.name: auto
values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-padding-block-end
properties.description: The scroll-padding-block-end property defines offsets for the end edge in the block dimension of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.

values.name: auto
values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-padding-block-start
properties.description: The scroll-padding-block-start property defines offsets for the start edge in the block dimension of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.

values.name: auto
values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-padding-bottom
properties.description: The scroll-padding-bottom property defines offsets for the bottom of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.

values.name: auto
values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-padding-inline
properties.description: The scroll-padding-inline shorthand property sets the scroll padding of an element in the inline dimension.

values.name: auto
