values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-padding-inline-end
properties.description: The scroll-padding-inline-end property defines offsets for the end edge in the inline dimension of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.

values.name: auto
values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-padding-inline-start
properties.description: The scroll-padding-inline-start property defines offsets for the start edge in the inline dimension of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.

values.name: auto
values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-padding-left
properties.description: The scroll-padding-left property defines offsets for the left of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.

values.name: auto
values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-padding-right
properties.description: The scroll-padding-right property defines offsets for the right of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.

values.name: auto
values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-padding-top
properties.description: The scroll-padding-top property defines offsets for the top of the optimal viewing region of the scrollport: the region used as the target region for placing things in view of the user. This allows the author to exclude regions of the scrollport that are obscured by other content (such as fixed-positioned toolbars or sidebars) or to put more breathing room between a targeted element and the edges of the scrollport.

values.name: auto
values.description: The offset is determined by the user agent. This will generally be 0px, but a user agent is able to detect and do something else if a non-zero value is more appropriate.

properties.name: scroll-snap-align
properties.description: The scroll-snap-align property specifies the box's snap position as an alignment of its snap area (as the alignment subject) within its snap container's snapport (as the alignment container). The two values specify the snapping alignment in the block axis and inline axis, respectively. If only one value is specified, the second value defaults to the same value.

values.name: none
values.description: The box does not define a snap position in that axis.

values.name: start
values.description: The start alignment of this box's scroll snap area, within the scroll container's snapport is a snap position in this axis.

values.name: end
values.description: The end alignment of this box's scroll snap area, within the scroll container's snapport is a snap position in this axis.

values.name: center
values.description: The center alignment of this box's scroll snap area, within the scroll container's snapport is a snap position in this axis.

properties.name: scroll-snap-coordinate

values.name: none
values.description: Specifies that this element does not contribute a snap point.

properties.description: Defines the x and y coordinate within the element which will align with the nearest ancestor scroll container's snap-destination for the respective axis.

properties.name: scroll-snap-destination
properties.description: Define the x and y coordinate within the scroll container's visual viewport which element snap points will align with.

properties.name: scroll-snap-points-x

values.name: none
values.description: No snap points are defined by this scroll container.

values.name: repeat()
values.description: Defines an interval at which snap points are defined, starting from the container's relevant start edge.

properties.description: Defines the positioning of snap points along the x axis of the scroll container it is applied to.

properties.name: scroll-snap-points-y

values.name: none
values.description: No snap points are defined by this scroll container.

values.name: repeat()
values.description: Defines an interval at which snap points are defined, starting from the container's relevant start edge.

properties.description: Defines the positioning of snap points along the y axis of the scroll container it is applied to.

properties.name: scroll-snap-stop

values.name: normal
values.description: When the visual viewport of this element's scroll container is scrolled, it may "pass over" possible snap positions.

values.name: always
values.description: The scroll container must not "pass over" a possible snap position; and must snap to the first of this elements' snap positions.

properties.description: The scroll-snap-stop CSS property defines whether or not the scroll container is allowed to "pass over" possible snap positions.

properties.name: scroll-snap-type

values.name: none
values.description: When the visual viewport of this scroll container is scrolled, it must ignore snap points.

values.name: mandatory
values.description: The visual viewport of this scroll container must snap to a snap position if it isn't currently scrolled.

values.name: proximity
values.description: The visual viewport of this scroll container may snap to a snap position if it isn't currently scrolled. The user agent decides if it snaps or not based on scroll parameters. This is the default snap strictness if any snap axis is specified.

values.name: x
values.description: The scroll container snaps to snap positions in its horizontal axis only.

values.name: y
values.description: The scroll container snaps to snap positions in its vertical axis only.

values.name: block
values.description: The scroll container snaps to snap positions in its block axis only.

values.name: inline
values.description: The scroll container snaps to snap positions in its inline axis only.

values.name: both
values.description: The scroll container snaps to snap positions in both of its axes independently (potentially snapping to different elements in each axis).

properties.syntax: none | [ x | y | block | inline | both ] [ mandatory | proximity ]?
properties.description: The scroll-snap-type CSS property sets how strictly snap points are enforced on the scroll container in case there is one.

properties.name: scroll-snap-type-x

values.name: none
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: mandatory
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: proximity
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description:
The scroll-snap-type-x CSS property defines how strictly snap points are enforced on the horizontal axis of the scroll container in case there is one.

Specifying any precise animations or physics used to enforce those snap points is not covered by this property but instead left up to the user agent.

properties.name: scroll-snap-type-y

values.name: none
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: mandatory
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: proximity
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description:
The scroll-snap-type-y CSS property defines how strictly snap points are enforced on the vertical axis of the scroll container in case there is one.

Specifying any precise animations or physics used to enforce those snap points is not covered by this property but instead left up to the user agent.

properties.name: scroll-timeline
properties.description: The scroll-timeline CSS shorthand property is used to define a named scroll progress timeline, which is progressed through by scrolling a scrollable element (scroller) between top and bottom (or left and right). scroll-timeline is set on the scroller that will provide the timeline. The starting scroll position represents 0% progress and the ending scroll position represents 100% progress. If the 0% position and 100% position coincide (i.e., the scroll container has no overflow to scroll), the timeline is inactive.

properties.name: scroll-timeline-axis
properties.description: The scroll-timeline-axis CSS property is used to specify the scrollbar direction that will be used to provide the timeline for a named scroll progress timeline animation, which is progressed through by scrolling a scrollable element (scroller) between top and bottom (or left and right). scroll-timeline is set on the scroller that will provide the timeline. See CSS scroll-driven animations for more details.

values.name: block
values.description: The scrollbar on the block axis of the scroller element, which is the axis in the direction perpendicular to the flow of text within a line. For horizontal writing modes, such as standard English, this is the same as y, while for vertical writing modes, it is the same as x. This is the default value.

values.name: inline
values.description: The scrollbar on the inline axis of the scroller element, which is the axis in the direction parallel to the flow of text in a line. For horizontal writing modes, this is the same as x, while for vertical writing modes, this is the same as y.

values.name: y
values.description: The scrollbar on the vertical axis of the scroller element.

values.name: x
values.description: The scrollbar on the horizontal axis of the scroller element.

properties.name: scroll-timeline-name
properties.description: The scroll-timeline-name CSS property is used to define the name of a named scroll progress timeline, which is progressed through by scrolling a scrollable element (scroller) between top and bottom (or left and right). scroll-timeline-name is set on the scroller that will provide the timeline.

values.name: none
values.description: The timeline has no name.

properties.name: scrollbar-3dlight-color
properties.description: Determines the color of the top and left edges of the scroll box and scroll arrows of a scroll bar.

properties.name: scrollbar-arrow-color
properties.description: Determines the color of the arrow elements of a scroll arrow.

properties.name: scrollbar-base-color
properties.description: Determines the color of the main elements of a scroll bar, which include the scroll box, track, and scroll arrows.

properties.name: scrollbar-color
properties.description: The scrollbar-color CSS property sets the color of the scrollbar track and thumb.

properties.name: scrollbar-darkshadow-color
properties.description: Determines the color of the gutter of a scroll bar.

properties.name: scrollbar-face-color
properties.description: Determines the color of the scroll box and scroll arrows of a scroll bar.

properties.name: scrollbar-gutter
properties.description: The scrollbar-gutter CSS property allows authors to reserve space for the scrollbar, preventing unwanted layout changes as the content grows while also avoiding unnecessary visuals when scrolling isn't needed.

values.name: auto
values.description: The initial value. Classic scrollbars create a gutter when overflow is scroll, or when overflow is auto and the box is overflowing. Overlay scrollbars do not consume space.

values.name: stable
values.description: When using classic scrollbars, the gutter will be present if overflow is auto, scroll, or hidden even if the box is not overflowing. When using overlay scrollbars, the gutter will not be present.

values.name: both-edges
values.description: If a gutter would be present on one of the inline start/end edges of the box, another will be present on the opposite edge as well.

properties.name: scrollbar-highlight-color
properties.description: Determines the color of the top and left edges of the scroll box and scroll arrows of a scroll bar.

properties.name: scrollbar-shadow-color
properties.description: Determines the color of the bottom and right edges of the scroll box and scroll arrows of a scroll bar.

properties.name: scrollbar-track-color
properties.description: Determines the color of the track element of a scroll bar.

properties.name: scrollbar-width

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: thin
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: none
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The scrollbar-width property allows the author to set the maximum thickness of an element's scrollbars when they are shown.

properties.name: shape-image-threshold
properties.description: The shape-image-threshold CSS property sets the alpha channel threshold used to extract the shape using an image as the value for shape-outside.

properties.name: shape-margin
properties.description: The shape-margin CSS property sets a margin for a CSS shape created using shape-outside.

properties.name: shape-outside

values.name: margin-box
values.description: Defines the shape enclosed by the outside margin edge. The corner radii of this shape are determined by the corresponding border-radius and margin values. If the border-radius / margin ratio is 1 or more, then the margin box corner radius is border-radius + margin. If the ratio is less than 1, then the margin box corner radius is border-radius + (margin * (1 + (ratio - 1) ^ 3)).

values.name: none
values.description: The float area is unaffected. Inline content wraps around the element's margin box, like usual.

values.name: border-box
values.description: Defines the shape enclosed by the outside border edge. The shape follows the normal border radius shaping rules for the outside of the border.

values.name: padding-box
values.description: Defines the shape enclosed by the outside padding edge. The shape follows the normal border radius shaping rules for the inside of the border.

values.name: content-box
values.description: Defines the shape enclosed by the outside content edge. Each corner radius of this box is the larger of 0 or border-radius - border-width - padding.

properties.description: The shape-outside CSS property defines a shape—which may be non-rectangular—around which adjacent inline content should wrap. By default, inline content wraps around its margin box; shape-outside provides a way to customize this wrapping, making it possible to wrap text around complex objects rather than simple boxes.

properties.name: shape-rendering

values.name: auto
values.description: Suppresses aural rendering.

values.name: crispEdges
values.description: Emphasize the contrast between clean edges of artwork over rendering speed and geometric precision.

values.name: geometricPrecision
values.description: Emphasize geometric precision over speed and crisp edges.

values.name: optimizeSpeed
values.description: Emphasize rendering speed over geometric precision and crisp edges.

properties.description: Provides hints about what tradeoffs to make as it renders vector graphics elements such as <path> elements and basic shapes such as circles and rectangles.

properties.name: size
properties.description: The size CSS at-rule descriptor, used with the @page at-rule, defines the size and orientation of the box which is used to represent a page. Most of the time, this size corresponds to the target size of the printed page if applicable.

properties.name: size-adjust
properties.description: A multiplier for glyph outlines and metrics of a font.

properties.name: speak-as
properties.description: The speak-as descriptor specifies how a counter symbol constructed with a given @counter-style will be represented in the spoken form. For example, an author can specify a counter symbol to be either spoken as its numerical value or just represented with an audio cue.

properties.name: src

values.name: url()
values.description: Reference font by URL

values.name: format()
values.description: Optional hint describing the format of the font resource.

values.name: local()
values.description: Format-specific string that identifies a locally available copy of a given font.

properties.description: @font-face descriptor. Specifies the resource containing font data. It is required, whether the font is downloadable or locally installed.

properties.name: stop-color
properties.description: Indicates what color to use at that gradient stop.

properties.name: stop-opacity
properties.description: Defines the opacity of a given gradient stop.

properties.name: stroke

values.name: url()
values.description: A URL reference to a paint server element, which is an element that defines a paint server: 'hatch', 'linearGradient', 'mesh', 'pattern', 'radialGradient' and 'solidcolor'.

values.name: none
values.description: No paint is applied in this layer.

properties.description: Paints along the outline of the given graphical element.

properties.name: stroke-dasharray

values.name: none
values.description: Indicates that no dashing is used.

properties.description: Controls the pattern of dashes and gaps used to stroke paths.

properties.name: stroke-dashoffset
properties.description: Specifies the distance into the dash pattern to start the dash.

properties.name: stroke-linecap

values.name: butt
values.description: Indicates that the stroke for each subpath does not extend beyond its two endpoints.

values.name: round
values.description: Indicates that at each end of each subpath, the shape representing the stroke will be extended by a half circle with a radius equal to the stroke width.

values.name: square
values.description: Indicates that at the end of each subpath, the shape representing the stroke will be extended by a rectangle with the same width as the stroke width and whose length is half of the stroke width.

properties.description: Specifies the shape to be used at the end of open subpaths when they are stroked.

properties.name: stroke-linejoin

values.name: bevel
values.description: Indicates that a bevelled corner is to be used to join path segments.

values.name: miter
values.description: Indicates that a sharp corner is to be used to join path segments.

values.name: round
values.description: Indicates that a round corner is to be used to join path segments.

properties.description: Specifies the shape to be used at the corners of paths or basic shapes when they are stroked.

properties.name: stroke-miterlimit
properties.description: When two line segments meet at a sharp angle and miter joins have been specified for 'stroke-linejoin', it is possible for the miter to extend far beyond the thickness of the line stroking the path.

properties.name: stroke-opacity
properties.description: Specifies the opacity of the painting operation used to stroke the current object.

properties.name: stroke-width
properties.description: Specifies the width of the stroke on the current object.

properties.name: suffix
properties.description: @counter-style descriptor. Specifies a <symbol> that is appended to the marker representation.

properties.name: symbols
properties.description: @counter-style descriptor. Specifies the symbols used by the marker-construction algorithm specified by the system descriptor.

properties.name: syntax
properties.description: Specifies the syntax of the custom property registration represented by the @property rule, controlling how the property’s value is parsed at computed value time.

properties.name: system

values.name: additive
values.description: Represents "sign-value" numbering systems, which, rather than using reusing digits in different positions to change their value, define additional digits with much larger values, so that the value of the number can be obtained by adding all the digits together.

values.name: alphabetic
values.description: Interprets the list of counter symbols as digits to an alphabetic numbering system, similar to the default lower-alpha counter style, which wraps from "a", "b", "c", to "aa", "ab", "ac".

values.name: cyclic
values.description: Cycles repeatedly through its provided symbols, looping back to the beginning when it reaches the end of the list.

values.name: extends
values.description: Use the algorithm of another counter style, but alter other aspects.

values.name: fixed
values.description: Runs through its list of counter symbols once, then falls back.

values.name: numeric
values.description: interprets the list of counter symbols as digits to a "place-value" numbering system, similar to the default 'decimal' counter style.

values.name: symbolic
values.description: Cycles repeatedly through its provided symbols, doubling, tripling, etc. the symbols on each successive pass through the list.

properties.syntax: cyclic | numeric | alphabetic | symbolic | additive | [ fixed <integer>? ] | [ extends <counter-style-name> ]
properties.description: @counter-style descriptor. Specifies which algorithm will be used to construct the counter's representation based on the counter value.

properties.name: tab-size
properties.description: The tab-size CSS property is used to customize the width of tab characters (U+0009).

properties.name: table-layout

values.name: auto
values.description: The automatic table layout algorithm is used. The widths of the table and its cells are adjusted to fit the content. Most browsers use this algorithm by default.

values.name: fixed
values.description:
The fixed table layout algorithm is used. When using this keyword, the table's width needs to be specified explicitly using the width property. If the value of the width property is set to autoor is not specified, the browser uses the automatic table layout algorithm, in which case the fixed value has no effect.The fixed table layout algorithm is faster than the automatic layout algorithm because the horizontal layout of the table depends only on the table's width, the width of the columns, and borders or cell spacing. The horizontal layout doesn't depend on the contents of the cells because it depends only on explicitly set widths.
    In the fixed table layout algorithm, the width of each column is determined as follows:
    
      A column element with explicit width sets the width for that column.
      Otherwise, a cell in the first row with explicit width determines the width for that column.
      Otherwise, the column gets the width from the shared remaining horizontal space.
    
    With this algorithm the entire table can be rendered once the first table row has been downloaded and analyzed. This can speed up rendering time over the "automatic" layout method, but subsequent cell content might not fit in the column widths provided. Cells use the overflow property to determine whether to clip any overflowing content, but only if the table has a known width; otherwise, they won't overflow the cells.

properties.description: The table-layout CSS property sets the algorithm used to lay out <table> cells, rows, and columns.

properties.name: text-align-last

values.name: auto
values.description: The affected line is aligned per the value of text-align, unless text-align is justify, in which case the effect is the same as setting text-align-last to start.

values.name: center
values.description: The inline contents are centered within the line box.

values.name: justify
values.description: The text is justified. Text should line up their left and right edges to the left and right content edges of the paragraph.

values.name: left
values.description: The inline contents are aligned to the left edge of the line box.

values.name: right
values.description: The inline contents are aligned to the right edge of the line box.

values.name: start
values.description: The same as left if direction is left-to-right and right if direction is right-to-left.

values.name: end
values.description: The same as right if direction is left-to-right and left if direction is right-to-left.

properties.syntax: auto | start | end | left | right | center | justify
properties.description: The text-align-last CSS property sets how the last line of a block or a line, right before a forced line break, is aligned.

properties.name: text-anchor

values.name: end
values.description: The rendered characters are aligned such that the end of the resulting rendered text is at the initial current text position.

values.name: middle
values.description: The rendered characters are aligned such that the geometric middle of the resulting rendered text is at the initial current text position.

values.name: start
values.description: The rendered characters are aligned such that the start of the resulting rendered text is at the initial current text position.

properties.description: Used to align (start-, middle- or end-alignment) a string of text relative to a given point.

properties.name: text-combine-upright
properties.description: The text-combine-upright CSS property sets the combination of characters into the space of a single character. If the combined text is wider than 1em, the user agent must fit the contents within 1em. The resulting composition is treated as a single upright glyph for layout and decoration. This property only has an effect in vertical writing modes.

values.name: none
values.description: There is no special processing.

values.name: all
values.description: Attempts to typeset all consecutive characters within the box horizontally, such that they take up the space of a single character within the vertical line of the box.

values.name: digits <integer>?
values.description: Attempts to display a sequence of consecutive ASCII digits (U+0030–U+0039) that has as many or fewer characters than the specified integer, such that it takes up the space of a single character within the vertical line box. If the integer is omitted, it computes to 2. Integers outside the range of 2-4 are invalid.

properties.name: text-decoration-skip
properties.syntax: none | [ objects || [ spaces | [ leading-spaces || trailing-spaces ] ] || edges || box-decoration ]
properties.description: The text-decoration-skip CSS property sets what parts of an element's content any text decoration affecting the element must skip over. It controls all text decoration lines drawn by the element and also any text decoration lines drawn by its ancestors.

values.name: none
values.description: Nothing is skipped. Thus, text decoration is drawn for all text content and across atomic inline-level boxes.

values.name: objects
values.description: The entire margin box of the element is skipped if it is an atomic inline such as an image or inline-block.

values.name: spaces
values.description: All spacing is skipped: all Unicode white space characters and all word separators, plus any adjacent letter-spacing or word-spacing.

values.name: leading-spaces
values.description: The same as spaces, except that only leading spaces are skipped.

values.name: trailing-spaces
values.description: The same as spaces, except that only trailing spaces are skipped.

values.name: edges
values.description: The start and end of the text decoration is inset slightly (e.g., by half of the line thickness) from the content edge of the decorating box. Thus, adjacent elements receive separate underlines. (This is important in Chinese, where underlining is a form of punctuation.)

values.name: box-decoration
values.description: The text decoration is skipped over the box's margin, border, and padding areas. This only has an effect on decorations imposed by an ancestor; a decorating box never draws over its own box decoration.

properties.name: text-decoration-skip-ink

values.name: auto
values.description: The default — the browser may interrupt underlines and overlines so that they do not touch or closely approach a glyph. That is, they are interrupted where they would otherwise cross over a glyph.

values.name: all
values.description: The browser must interrupt underlines and overlines so that they do not touch or closely approach a glyph. This can be helpful with certain Chinese, Japanese, or Korean (CJK) fonts, where the auto behavior might not create interruptions.

values.name: none
values.description: Underlines and overlines are drawn across the full length of the text content, including parts that cross over glyph descenders and ascenders.

properties.description: The text-decoration-skip-ink CSS property specifies how overlines and underlines are drawn when they pass over glyph ascenders and descenders.

properties.name: text-emphasis
properties.description: The text-emphasis CSS property applies emphasis marks to text (except spaces and control characters). It is a shorthand for text-emphasis-style and text-emphasis-color.

values.name: none
values.description: No emphasis marks.

values.name: filled
values.description: The shape is filled with solid color. If neither filled nor open is present, this is the default.

values.name: open
values.description: The shape is hollow.

values.name: dot
values.description: Display small circles as marks. The filled dot is '•' (U+2022), and the open dot is '◦' (U+25E6).

values.name: circle
values.description: Display large circles as marks. The filled circle is '●' (U+25CF), and the open circle is '○' (U+25CB). This is the default shape in horizontal writing modes when no other shape is given.

values.name: double-circle
values.description: Display double circles as marks. The filled double-circle is '◉' (U+25C9), and the open double-circle is '◎' (U+25CE).

values.name: triangle
values.description: Display triangles as marks. The filled triangle is '▲' (U+25B2), and the open triangle is '△' (U+25B3).

values.name: sesame
values.description: Display sesames as marks. The filled sesame is '﹅' (U+FE45), and the open sesame is '﹆' (U+FE46). This is the default shape in vertical writing modes when no other shape is given.

properties.name: text-emphasis-color
properties.description: The text-emphasis-color CSS property sets the color of emphasis marks. This value can also be set using the text-emphasis shorthand.

properties.name: text-emphasis-position
properties.description: The text-emphasis-position CSS property sets where emphasis marks are drawn. Like ruby text, if there isn't enough room for emphasis marks, the line height is increased.

values.name: over
values.description: Draws marks over the text in horizontal writing mode.

values.name: under
values.description: Draws marks under the text in horizontal writing mode.

values.name: right
values.description: Draws marks to the right of the text in vertical writing mode.

values.name: left
values.description: Draws marks to the left of the text in vertical writing mode.

properties.name: text-emphasis-style
properties.syntax: none | [ [ filled | open ] || [ dot | circle | double-circle | triangle | sesame ] ] | <string>
properties.description: The text-emphasis-style CSS property sets the appearance of emphasis marks. It can also be set, and reset, using the text-emphasis shorthand.

values.name: none
values.description: No emphasis marks.

values.name: filled
values.description: The shape is filled with solid color. If neither filled nor open is present, this is the default.

values.name: open
values.description: The shape is hollow.

values.name: dot
values.description: Display small circles as marks. The filled dot is '•' (U+2022), and the open dot is '◦' (U+25E6).

values.name: circle
values.description: Display large circles as marks. The filled circle is '●' (U+25CF), and the open circle is '○' (U+25CB).

values.name: double-circle
values.description: Display double circles as marks. The filled double-circle is '◉' (U+25C9), and the open double-circle is '◎' (U+25CE).

values.name: triangle
values.description: Display triangles as marks. The filled triangle is '▲' (U+25B2), and the open triangle is '△' (U+25B3).

values.name: sesame
values.description: Display sesames as marks. The filled sesame is '﹅' (U+FE45), and the open sesame is '﹆' (U+FE46).

properties.name: text-indent

values.name: each-line
values.description: Indentation affects the first line of the block container as well as each line after a forced line break, but does not affect lines after a soft wrap break.

values.name: hanging
values.description: Inverts which lines are indented. All lines except the first line will be indented.

properties.description: The text-indent CSS property sets the length of empty space (indentation) that is put before lines of text in a block.

properties.name: text-justify

values.name: auto
values.description: The browser chooses the best type of justification for the current situation based on a balance between performance and quality, but also on what is most appropriate for the language of the text (e.g., English, CJK languages, etc.). This is the default justification used if text-justify is not set at all.

values.name: distribute
values.description: Exhibits the same behavior as inter-character; this value is kept for backwards compatibility.

values.name: distribute-all-lines
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: inter-cluster
values.description: Justification primarily changes spacing at word separators and at grapheme cluster boundaries in clustered scripts. This value is typically used for Southeast Asian scripts such as Thai.

values.name: inter-ideograph
values.description: Justification primarily changes spacing at word separators and at inter-graphemic boundaries in scripts that use no word spaces. This value is typically used for CJK languages.

values.name: inter-word
values.description: The text is justified by adding space between words (effectively varying word-spacing), which is most appropriate for languages that separate words using spaces, like English or Korean.

values.name: kashida
values.description: Justification primarily stretches Arabic and related scripts through the use of kashida or other calligraphic elongation.

values.name: newspaper
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: none
values.description: The text justification is turned off. This has the same effect as not setting text-align at all, although it is useful if you need to turn justification on and off for some reason.

values.name: inter-character
values.description: The text is justified by adding space between characters (effectively varying letter-spacing), which is most appropriate for languages like Japanese.

properties.description: The text-justify CSS property sets what type of justification should be applied to text when text-align: justify; is set on an element.

properties.name: text-orientation

values.name: sideways
values.description: Causes characters to be laid out as they would be horizontally, but with the whole line rotated 90° clockwise.

values.name: sideways-right
values.description: An alias to sideways that is kept for compatibility purposes.

values.name: upright
values.description: Lays out the characters of horizontal scripts naturally (upright), as well as the glyphs for vertical scripts. Note that this keyword causes all characters to be considered as left-to-right: the used value of direction is forced to be ltr.

values.name: mixed
values.description: Rotates the characters of horizontal scripts 90° clockwise. Lays out the characters of vertical scripts naturally. Default value.

values.name: use-glyph-orientation
values.description: On SVG elements, this keyword leads to use the value of the deprecated SVG properties glyph-orientation-vertical and glyph-orientation-horizontal.

properties.description: The text-orientation CSS property sets the orientation of the text characters in a line. It only affects text in vertical mode (when writing-mode is not horizontal-tb). It is useful for controlling the display of languages that use vertical script, and also for making vertical table headers.

properties.name: text-rendering

values.name: auto
values.description: The browser makes educated guesses about when to optimize for speed, legibility, and geometric precision while drawing text. For differences in how this value is interpreted by the browser, see the compatibility table.

values.name: geometricPrecision
values.description:
The browser emphasizes geometric precision over rendering speed and legibility. Certain aspects of fonts — such as kerning — don't scale linearly. So this value can make text using those fonts look good.
    In SVG, when text is scaled up or down, browsers calculate the final size of the text (which is determined by the specified font size and the applied scale) and request a font of that computed size from the platform's font system. But if you request a font size of, say, 9 with a scale of 140%, the resulting font size of 12.6 doesn't explicitly exist in the font system, so the browser rounds the font size to 12 instead. This results in stair-step scaling of text.
    But the geometricPrecision property — when fully supported by the rendering engine — lets you scale your text fluidly. For large scale factors, you might see less-than-beautiful text rendering, but the size is what you would expect—neither rounded up nor down to the nearest font size supported by Windows or Linux.
    
      Note: WebKit precisely applies the specified value, but Gecko treats the value the same as optimizeLegibility.

values.name: optimizeLegibility
values.description: The browser emphasizes legibility over rendering speed and geometric precision. This enables kerning and optional ligatures.

values.name: optimizeSpeed
values.description: The browser emphasizes rendering speed over legibility and geometric precision when drawing text. It disables kerning and ligatures.

properties.description: The text-rendering CSS property provides information to the rendering engine about what to optimize for when rendering text.

properties.name: text-shadow

values.name: none
values.description: No shadow.

properties.description: The text-shadow CSS property adds shadows to text. It accepts a comma-separated list of shadows to be applied to the text and any of its decorations. Each shadow is described by some combination of X and Y offsets from the element, blur radius, and color.

properties.name: text-size-adjust
properties.description: The text-size-adjust CSS property controls the text inflation algorithm used on some smartphones and tablets. Other browsers will ignore this property.

values.name: none
values.description: Disables the browser's inflation algorithm.

values.name: auto
values.description: Enables the browser's inflation algorithm. This value is used to cancel a none value previously set with CSS.

properties.name: text-transform

values.name: capitalize
values.description: Puts the first typographic letter unit of each word in titlecase.

values.name: lowercase
values.description: Puts all letters in lowercase.

values.name: none
values.description: No effects.

values.name: uppercase
values.description: Puts all letters in uppercase.

values.name: full-width
values.description: 是一个关键字，它强制将字符（主要是表意文字和拉丁文字））--写在一个正方形内，使它们能够在通常的东亚文字（如中文或日文）中对齐。

values.name: full-size-kana
values.description: 通常用于 <ruby> 注释文本，该关键字将所有小假名字符转换为等效的全尺寸假名，以补偿在 ruby 中通常使用的小字体的可读性问题。

properties.syntax: none | capitalize | uppercase | lowercase | full-width | full-size-kana
properties.description: The text-transform CSS property specifies how to capitalize an element's text. It can be used to make text appear in all-uppercase or all-lowercase, or with each word capitalized. It also can help improve legibility for ruby.

properties.name: text-underline-offset
properties.description: The text-underline-offset CSS property sets the offset distance of an underline text decoration line (applied using text-decoration) from its original position.

values.name: auto
values.description: The browser chooses the appropriate offset for underlines.

properties.name: text-underline-position

values.name: above
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: auto
values.description: The user agent uses its own algorithm to place the line at or under the alphabetic baseline.

values.name: below
values.description: The underline is aligned with the under edge of the element's content box.

values.name: from-font
values.description: If the font file includes information about a preferred position, use that value. If the font file doesn't include this information, behave as if auto was set, with the browser choosing an appropriate position.

values.name: under
values.description: Forces the line to be set below the alphabetic baseline, at a position where it won't cross any descenders. This is useful for ensuring legibility with chemical and mathematical formulas, which make a large use of subscripts.

values.name: left
values.description: In vertical writing-modes, this keyword forces the line to be placed on the left side of the text. In horizontal writing-modes, it is a synonym of under.

values.name: right
values.description: In vertical writing-modes, this keyword forces the line to be placed on the right side of the text. In horizontal writing-modes, it is a synonym of under.

values.name: auto-pos
values.description: auto的同义词，应使用 auto。

properties.description: The text-underline-position CSS property specifies the position of the underline which is set using the text-decoration property's underline value.

properties.name: text-wrap

values.name: wrap
values.description: Text is wrapped across lines at appropriate characters (for example spaces, in languages like English that use space separators) to minimize overflow. This is the default value.

values.name: nowrap
values.description: Text does not wrap across lines. It will overflow its containing element rather than breaking onto a new line.

values.name: balance
values.description: Text is wrapped in a way that best balances the number of characters on each line, enhancing layout quality and legibility. Because counting characters and balancing them across multiple lines is computationally expensive, this value is only supported for blocks of text spanning a limited number of lines (the Chromium implementation uses six wrapped lines or less), meaning that it is useful for cases such as headings or pull quotes.

values.name: stable
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: pretty
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The text-wrap CSS property controls how text inside an element is wrapped. The different values provide:

properties.name: timeline-scope
properties.description: The timeline-scope CSS property modifies the scope of a named animation timeline.

values.name: none
values.description: There is no change in timeline scope.

properties.name: touch-action

values.name: auto
values.description: Enable browser handling of all panning and zooming gestures.

values.name: cross-slide-x
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: cross-slide-y
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: double-tap-zoom
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: manipulation
values.description: Enable panning and pinch zoom gestures, but disable additional non-standard gestures such as double-tap to zoom. Disabling double-tap to zoom removes the need for browsers to delay the generation of click events when the user taps the screen. This is an alias for "pan-x pan-y pinch-zoom" (which, for compatibility, is itself still valid).

values.name: none
values.description: Disable browser handling of all panning and zooming gestures.

values.name: pan-x
values.description: Enable single-finger horizontal panning gestures. May be combined with pan-y, pan-up, pan-down and/or pinch-zoom.

values.name: pan-y
values.description: Enable single-finger vertical panning gestures. May be combined with pan-x, pan-left, pan-right and/or pinch-zoom.

values.name: pinch-zoom
values.description: Enable multi-finger panning and zooming of the page. This may be combined with any of the pan- values.

values.name: pan-left
values.description: Enable single-finger gestures that begin by scrolling in the given direction(s). Once scrolling has started, the direction may still be reversed. Note that scrolling "up" (pan-up) means that the user is dragging their finger downward on the screen surface, and likewise pan-left means the user is dragging their finger to the right. Multiple directions may be combined except when there is a simpler representation (for example, "pan-left pan-right" is invalid since "pan-x" is simpler, but "pan-left pan-down" is valid).

values.name: pan-right
values.description: Enable single-finger gestures that begin by scrolling in the given direction(s). Once scrolling has started, the direction may still be reversed. Note that scrolling "up" (pan-up) means that the user is dragging their finger downward on the screen surface, and likewise pan-left means the user is dragging their finger to the right. Multiple directions may be combined except when there is a simpler representation (for example, "pan-left pan-right" is invalid since "pan-x" is simpler, but "pan-left pan-down" is valid).

values.name: pan-up
values.description: Enable single-finger gestures that begin by scrolling in the given direction(s). Once scrolling has started, the direction may still be reversed. Note that scrolling "up" (pan-up) means that the user is dragging their finger downward on the screen surface, and likewise pan-left means the user is dragging their finger to the right. Multiple directions may be combined except when there is a simpler representation (for example, "pan-left pan-right" is invalid since "pan-x" is simpler, but "pan-left pan-down" is valid).

values.name: pan-down
values.description: Enable single-finger gestures that begin by scrolling in the given direction(s). Once scrolling has started, the direction may still be reversed. Note that scrolling "up" (pan-up) means that the user is dragging their finger downward on the screen surface, and likewise pan-left means the user is dragging their finger to the right. Multiple directions may be combined except when there is a simpler representation (for example, "pan-left pan-right" is invalid since "pan-x" is simpler, but "pan-left pan-down" is valid).

values.name: pan-right,pan-up,pan-down
values.description: 启用以指定方向滚动开始的单指手势。一旦滚动开始，方向可能仍然相反。请注意，滚动“向上”（pan-up）意味着用户正在将其手指向下拖动到屏幕表面上，同样 pan-left 表示用户将其手指向右拖动。多个方向可以组合，除非有更简单的表示（例如，“pan-left pan-right”无效，因为“pan-x”更简单，而“pan-left pan-down”有效）。

properties.syntax: auto | none | [ [ pan-x | pan-left | pan-right ] || [ pan-y | pan-up | pan-down ] || pinch-zoom ] | manipulation
properties.description: The touch-action CSS property sets how an element's region can be manipulated by a touchscreen user (for example, by zooming features built into the browser).

properties.name: transform-box

values.name: content-box
values.description: The content box is used as the reference box. The reference box of a <table> is the border box of its table wrapper box, not its table box.

values.name: border-box
values.description: The border box is used as the reference box. The reference box of a <table> is the border box of its table wrapper box, not its table box.

values.name: fill-box
values.description: The object bounding box is used as the reference box. For elements with associated CSS layout box, acts as content-box.

values.name: stroke-box
values.description: The stroke bounding box is used as the reference box. For elements with associated CSS layout box, acts as border-box.

values.name: view-box
values.description: The nearest SVG viewport is used as the reference box. If a viewBox attribute is specified for the SVG viewport creating element, the reference box is positioned at the origin of the coordinate system established by the viewBox attribute, and the dimension of the reference box is set to the width and height values of the viewBox attribute. For elements with associated CSS layout box, acts as border-box.

properties.description: The transform-box CSS property defines the layout box to which the transform, individual transform properties translate,scale, and rotate, and transform-origin properties relate.

properties.name: transform-style

values.name: flat
values.description: Indicates that the children of the element are lying in the plane of the element itself.

values.name: preserve-3d
values.description: Indicates that the children of the element should be positioned in the 3D-space.

properties.description: The transform-style CSS property sets whether children of an element are positioned in the 3D space or are flattened in the plane of the element.

properties.name: translate
properties.description: The translate CSS property allows you to specify translation transforms individually and independently of the transform property. This maps better to typical user interface usage, and saves having to remember the exact order of transform functions to specify in the transform value.

values.name: none
values.description: Specifies that no translation should be applied.

properties.name: unicode-bidi

values.name: bidi-override
values.description: For inline elements this creates an override. For block container elements this creates an override for inline-level descendants not within another block container element. This means that inside the element, reordering is strictly in sequence according to the direction property; the implicit part of the bidirectional algorithm is ignored.

values.name: embed
values.description: If the element is inline, this value opens an additional level of embedding with respect to the bidirectional algorithm. The direction of this embedding level is given by the direction property.

values.name: isolate
values.description: This keyword indicates that the element's container directionality should be calculated without considering the content of this element. The element is therefore isolated from its siblings. When applying its bidirectional-resolution algorithm, its container element treats it as one or several U+FFFC Object Replacement Character, i.e. like an image.

values.name: isolate-override
values.description: This keyword applies the isolation behavior of the isolate keyword to the surrounding content and the override behavior of the bidi-override keyword to the inner content.

values.name: normal
values.description: The element does not offer an additional level of embedding with respect to the bidirectional algorithm. For inline elements, implicit reordering works across element boundaries.

values.name: plaintext
values.description:
This keyword makes the elements directionality calculated without considering its parent bidirectional state or the value of the direction property. The directionality is calculated using the P2 and P3 rules of the Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm.
      This value allows the display of data that is already formatted using a tool following the Unicode Bidirectional Algorithm.

properties.syntax: normal | embed | isolate | bidi-override | isolate-override | plaintext
properties.description: The unicode-bidi CSS property, together with the direction property, determines how bidirectional text in a document is handled. For example, if a block of content contains both left-to-right and right-to-left text, the user-agent uses a complex Unicode algorithm to decide how to display the text. The unicode-bidi property overrides this algorithm and allows the developer to control the text embedding.

values.name: U+26
values.description: Ampersand.
