properties.description: @font-face descriptor. Defines the set of Unicode codepoints that may be supported by the font face for which it is declared.

properties.name: user-modify

values.name: read-only
values.description: Default value. Contents are read-only.

values.name: read-write
values.description: The user is able to read and write contents.

values.name: read-write-plaintext-only
values.description: Same as read-write, but rich text formatting will be lost.

values.name: write-only
values.description: The user is able to edit the content, but not to read it.

properties.description: The user-modify property has no effect in Firefox. It was originally planned to determine whether or not the content of an element can be edited by a user.

properties.name: user-select

values.name: all
values.description: The content of the element shall be selected atomically: If a selection would contain part of the element, then the selection must contain the entire element including all its descendants. If a double-click or context-click occurred in sub-elements, the highest ancestor with this value will be selected.

values.name: auto
values.description:
The used value of auto is determined as follows:
    
      On the ::before and ::after pseudo elements, the used value is none
      If the element is an editable element, the used value is contain
      Otherwise, if the used value of user-select on the parent of this element is all, the used value is all
      Otherwise, if the used value of user-select on the parent of this element is none, the used value is none
      Otherwise, the used value is text

values.name: contain
values.description:
Enables selection to start within the element; however, the selection will be contained by the bounds of that element.
    
      Note: CSS UI 4 renamed the element value to contain.

values.name: none
values.description: The text of the element and its sub-elements is not selectable. Note that the Selection object can contain these elements.

values.name: text
values.description: The text can be selected by the user.

properties.description: The user-select CSS property controls whether the user can select text. This doesn't have any effect on content loaded as part of a browser's user interface (its chrome), except in textboxes.

properties.name: user-zoom

values.name: zoom
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: fixed
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The user-zoom CSS descriptor controls whether or not the user can change the zoom factor of a document defined by @viewport.

properties.name: vertical-align

values.name: auto
values.description: Align the dominant baseline of the parent box with the equivalent, or heuristically reconstructed, baseline of the element inline box.

values.name: baseline
values.description: Align the 'alphabetic' baseline of the element with the 'alphabetic' baseline of the parent element.

values.name: bottom
values.description: Align the after edge of the extended inline box with the after-edge of the line box.

values.name: middle
values.description: Align the 'middle' baseline of the inline element with the middle baseline of the parent.

values.name: sub
values.description: Lower the baseline of the box to the proper position for subscripts of the parent's box. (This value has no effect on the font size of the element's text.)

values.name: super
values.description: Raise the baseline of the box to the proper position for superscripts of the parent's box. (This value has no effect on the font size of the element's text.)

values.name: text-bottom
values.description: Align the bottom of the box with the after-edge of the parent element's font.

values.name: text-top
values.description: Align the top of the box with the before-edge of the parent element's font.

values.name: top
values.description: Align the before edge of the extended inline box with the before-edge of the line box.

values.name: -webkit-baseline-middle
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.syntax: baseline | sub | super | text-top | text-bottom | middle | top | bottom | <percentage> | <length>
properties.description: The vertical-align CSS property sets vertical alignment of an inline, inline-block or table-cell box.

properties.name: view-timeline
properties.description: The view-timeline CSS shorthand property is used to define a named view progress timeline, which is progressed through based on the change in visibility of an element (known as the subject) inside a scrollable element (scroller). view-timeline is set on the subject.

properties.name: view-timeline-axis
properties.description: The view-timeline-axis CSS property is used to specify the scrollbar direction that will be used to provide the timeline for a named view progress timeline animation, which is progressed through based on the change in visibility of an element (known as the subject) inside a scrollable element (scroller). view-timeline-axis is set on the subject. See CSS scroll-driven animations for more details.

values.name: block
values.description: The scrollbar on the block axis of the scroller element, which is the axis in the direction perpendicular to the flow of text within a line. For horizontal writing modes, such as standard English, this is the same as y, while for vertical writing modes, it is the same as x. This is the default value.

values.name: inline
values.description: The scrollbar on the inline axis of the scroller element, which is the axis in the direction parallel to the flow of text in a line. For horizontal writing modes, this is the same as x, while for vertical writing modes, this is the same as y.

values.name: y
values.description: The scrollbar on the vertical axis of the scroller element.

values.name: x
values.description: The scrollbar on the horizontal axis of the scroller element.

properties.name: view-timeline-inset
properties.description: The view-timeline-inset CSS property is used to specify one or two values representing an adjustment to the position of the scrollport (see Scroll container for more details) in which the subject element of a named view progress timeline animation is deemed to be visible. Put another way, this allows you to specify start and/or end inset (or outset) values that offset the position of the timeline.

values.name: auto
values.description: If set, the corresponding scroll-padding (or equivalent longhand value) for that edge of the scrollport is used. If this is not set (or set to auto), the value will usually be 0, although some user agents may use heuristics to determine a different default value if appropriate.

properties.name: view-timeline-name
properties.description: The view-timeline-name CSS property is used to define the name of a named view progress timeline, which is progressed through based on the change in visibility of an element (known as the subject) inside a scrollable element (scroller). view-timeline is set on the subject.

values.name: none
values.description: The timeline has no name.

properties.name: view-transition-name
properties.description: The view-transition-name CSS property provides the selected element with a distinct identifying name (a <custom-ident>) and causes it to participate in a separate view transition from the root view transition — or no view transition if the none value is specified.

values.name: none
values.description: The selected element will not participate in a view transition.

properties.name: viewport-fit

values.name: auto
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: contain
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: cover
values.description: No description on MDN

properties.description: The border-block-style CSS property defines the style of the logical block borders of an element, which maps to a physical border style depending on the element's writing mode, directionality, and text orientation.

properties.name: white-space-collapse
properties.syntax: collapse | discard | preserve | preserve-breaks | preserve-spaces | break-spaces

values.name: collapse
values.description: White space sequences are collapsed.

values.name: discard
values.description: No description on MDN

values.name: preserve
values.description: White space sequences and segment break characters are preserved.

values.name: preserve-breaks
values.description: White space sequences are collapsed, while segment break characters are preserved.

values.name: preserve-spaces
values.description: White space sequences are preserved, while tabs and segment break characters are converted to spaces.

values.name: break-spaces
values.description:
The behavior is identical to preserve, except that:
    
      Any sequence of preserved white space always takes up space, including at the end of the line.
      A line-breaking opportunity exists after every preserved white space character, including between white space characters.
      Preserved spaces take up space and do not hang, thus affecting the box's intrinsic sizes (min-content size and max-content size).

properties.description: The white-space-collapse CSS property controls how white space inside an element is collapsed.

properties.name: white-space-trim
properties.description: No description on MDN

properties.name: widows
properties.description: The widows CSS property sets the minimum number of lines in a block container that must be shown at the top of a page, region, or column.

properties.name: will-change

values.name: auto
values.description: This keyword expresses no particular intent; the user agent should apply whatever heuristics and optimizations it normally does.

values.name: contents
values.description: Indicates that the author expects to animate or change something about the element's contents in the near future.

values.name: scroll-position
values.description: Indicates that the author expects to animate or change the scroll position of the element in the near future.

properties.description: The will-change CSS property hints to browsers how an element is expected to change. Browsers may set up optimizations before an element is actually changed. These kinds of optimizations can increase the responsiveness of a page by doing potentially expensive work before they are actually required.

properties.name: word-break

values.name: break-all
values.description: To prevent overflow, word breaks should be inserted between any two characters (excluding Chinese/Japanese/Korean text).

values.name: keep-all
values.description: Word breaks should not be used for Chinese/Japanese/Korean (CJK) text. Non-CJK text behavior is the same as for normal.

values.name: normal
values.description: Use the default line break rule.

values.name: break-word
values.description: Has the same effect as overflow-wrap: anywhere combined with word-break: normal, regardless of the actual value of the overflow-wrap property.

properties.description: The word-break CSS property sets whether line breaks appear wherever the text would otherwise overflow its content box.

properties.name: word-spacing

values.name: normal
values.description: The normal inter-word spacing, as defined by the current font and/or the browser.

properties.description: The word-spacing CSS property sets the length of space between words and between tags.

properties.name: word-wrap

values.name: break-word
values.description: An otherwise unbreakable sequence of characters may be broken at an arbitrary point if there are no otherwise-acceptable break points in the line.

values.name: normal
values.description: Lines may break only at allowed break points.

properties.description: Specifies whether the UA may break within a word to prevent overflow when an otherwise-unbreakable string is too long to fit.

properties.name: writing-mode

values.name: horizontal-tb
values.description: For ltr scripts, content flows horizontally from left to right. For rtl scripts, content flows horizontally from right to left. The next horizontal line is positioned below the previous line.

values.name: sideways-lr
values.description: For ltr scripts, content flows vertically from bottom to top. For rtl scripts, content flows vertically from top to bottom. All the glyphs, even those in vertical scripts, are set sideways toward the left.

values.name: sideways-rl
values.description: For ltr scripts, content flows vertically from top to bottom. For rtl scripts, content flows vertically from bottom to top. All the glyphs, even those in vertical scripts, are set sideways toward the right.

values.name: vertical-lr
values.description: For ltr scripts, content flows vertically from top to bottom, and the next vertical line is positioned to the right of the previous line. For rtl scripts, content flows vertically from bottom to top, and the next vertical line is positioned to the left of the previous line.

values.name: vertical-rl
values.description: For ltr scripts, content flows vertically from top to bottom, and the next vertical line is positioned to the left of the previous line. For rtl scripts, content flows vertically from bottom to top, and the next vertical line is positioned to the right of the previous line.

values.name: lr
values.description: Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use horizontal-tb instead.

values.name: lr-tb
values.description: Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use horizontal-tb instead.

values.name: rl
values.description: Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use horizontal-tb instead.

values.name: tb
values.description: Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use vertical-lr instead.

values.name: tb-lr
values.description: Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use vertical-lr instead.

values.name: tb-rl
values.description: Deprecated except for SVG1 documents. For CSS, use vertical-rl instead.

properties.description: The writing-mode CSS property sets whether lines of text are laid out horizontally or vertically, as well as the direction in which blocks progress. When set for an entire document, it should be set on the root element (html element for HTML documents).

properties.name: zoom

values.name: normal
values.description: Render this element at its normal size.

values.name: reset
values.description: Do not (de)magnify this element if the user applies non-pinch-based zooming (e.g. by pressing Ctrl - - or Ctrl + + keyboard shortcuts) to the document. Do not use this value, use the standard unset value instead.

properties.description: The non-standard zoom CSS property can be used to control the magnification level of an element. transform: scale() should be used instead of this property, if possible. However, unlike CSS Transforms, zoom affects the layout size of the element.

atDirectives.name: @charset
atDirectives.description: @charset CSS @规则指定样式表中使用的字符编码。它必须是样式表中的第一个元素，而前面不得有任何字符。因为它不是一个嵌套语句，所以不能在@规则条件组中使用。如果有多个 @charset @规则被声明，只有第一个会被使用，而且不能在 HTML 元素或 HTML 页面的字符集相关 <style> 元素内的样式属性内使用。

atDirectives.name: @color-profile
atDirectives.description: @color-profile CSS at-rule 定义并命名一个颜色配置文件，稍后可以在 color() 函数中使用该配置文件来指定颜色。

atDirectives.name: @container
atDirectives.description: @container CSS at-rule 是将样式应用于包含上下文的条件组规则。 样式声明按条件筛选，如果条件为 true，则应用于容器。 当容器更改大小时，将评估条件。你还可以给这个收纳盒贴上一个名字，这样它就会专门整理那些名字相同的容器。当它整理容器的时候，会仔细检查每个容器的所有细节，确保所有条件都符合才会应用样式。

atDirectives.name: @counter-style
atDirectives.description: @counter-style 是一个 CSS at-rule ，它让开发者可以自定义 counter 的样式。一个 @counter-style 规则定义了如何把一个计数器的值转化为字符串表示。

atDirectives.name: @document
atDirectives.description: @document CSS at 规则根据文档的 URL 限制其中包含的样式规则。它主要用于用户定义的样式表，但也可用于作者定义的样式表。

atDirectives.name: @font-face
atDirectives.description: @font-face CSS at-rule 指定一个用于显示文本的自定义字体；字体能从远程服务器或者用户本地安装的字体加载。如果提供了 local() 函数，从用户本地查找指定的字体名称，并且找到了一个匹配项，本地字体就会被使用。否则，字体就会使用 url() 函数下载的资源。通过允许作者提供他们自己的字体，@font-face 让设计内容成为了一种可能，同时并不会被所谓的"网络 - 安全"字体所限制 (字体如此普遍以至于它们能被广泛的使用). 指定查找和使用本地安装的字体名称可以让字体的自定义化程度超过基本字体，同时在不依赖网络情况下实现此功能。在同时使用 url() 和 local() 功能时，为了用户已经安装的字体副本在需要使用时被使用，如果在用户本地没有找到字体副本就会去使用户下载的副本查找字体。@font-face 规则不仅仅使用在 CSS 的顶层，还可以用在任何 CSS 条件组规则中。

values.name: font-family
values.description: 所指定的字体名字将会被用于 font 或 font-family 属性 ( i.e. font-family: <family-name>; )

values.name: src
values.description: 远程字体文件位置的 URL 或者用户计算机上的字体名称，可以使用 local 语法通过名称指定用户的本地计算机上的字体 ( i.e. src: local('Arial'); )。如果找不到该字体，将会尝试其他来源，直到找到它。

values.name: font-variant
values.description: A font-variant value.

values.name: font-stretch
values.description: A font-stretch value.

values.name: font-weight
values.description: A font-weight value.

values.name: font-style
values.description: 对于 src 所指字体的描述。如果所需字体符合描述，则采用本 font-face 所定义的字体。

values.name: unicode-range
values.description: 在该 @font-face 中定义的 unicode 字体范围

atDirectives.name: @font-feature-values
atDirectives.description: @font-feature-values CSS at-rule 允许作者在font-variant-alternates 中使用通用名称，用于在 OpenType 中以不同方式激活功能。它允许在使用几种字体时简化 CSS。

atDirectives.name: @font-palette-values
atDirectives.description: @font-palette-values CSS at-rule 允许您自定义字体制作者创建的字体调色板的默认值。

atDirectives.name: @import
atDirectives.description: @import CSS@规则，用于从其他样式表导入样式规则。这些规则必须先于所有其他类型的规则，@charset 规则除外; 因为它不是一个嵌套语句，@import 不能在条件组的规则中使用。

atDirectives.name: @keyframes
atDirectives.description: 关键帧 @keyframes at-rule 规则通过在动画序列中定义关键帧（或 waypoints）的样式来控制 CSS 动画序列中的中间步骤。和 转换 transition 相比，关键帧 keyframes 可以控制动画序列的中间步骤。

values.name: from
values.description: 等价于 0%。

atDirectives.name: @layer
atDirectives.description: CSS @规则 中的@layer声明了一个 级联层，同一层内的规则将级联在一起，这给予了开发者对层叠机制的更多控制。

atDirectives.name: @media
atDirectives.description: @media CSS at 规则可用于基于一个或多个媒体查询的结果来应用样式表的一部分。使用它，你可以指定一个媒体查询和一个 CSS 块，当且仅当该媒体查询与正在使用其内容的设备匹配时，该 CSS 块才能应用于该文档。

atDirectives.name: @namespace
atDirectives.description: @namespace 是用来定义使用在 CSS 样式表中的 XML 命名空间的 @规则。定义的命名空间可以把通配、元素和属性选择器限制在指定命名空间里的元素。@namespace规则通常在处理包含多个 namespaces 的文档时才有用，比如 HTML5 里内联的 SVG、MathML 或者混合多个词汇表的 XML。

atDirectives.name: @page
atDirectives.description: @page 规则用于在打印文档时修改某些 CSS 属性。

atDirectives.name: @property
atDirectives.description: @property CSS at-rule是CSS Houdini API 的一部分，它允许开发者显式地定义他们的CSS 自定义属性, 允许进行属性类型检查、设定默认值以及定义该自定义属性是否可以被继承。

atDirectives.name: @supports
atDirectives.description: @supports CSS at-rule 你可以指定依赖于浏览器中的一个或多个特定的 CSS 功能的支持声明。这被称为特性查询。该规则可以放在代码的顶层，也可以嵌套在任何其他条件组规则中。

atDirectives.name: @-moz-document
atDirectives.description: Gecko-specific at-rule that restricts the style rules contained within it based on the URL of the document.

atDirectives.name: @-moz-keyframes
atDirectives.description: Defines set of animation key frames.

atDirectives.name: @-ms-viewport
atDirectives.description: Specifies the size, zoom factor, and orientation of the viewport.

atDirectives.name: @-o-keyframes
atDirectives.description: Defines set of animation key frames.

atDirectives.name: @-o-viewport
atDirectives.description: Specifies the size, zoom factor, and orientation of the viewport.

atDirectives.name: @-webkit-keyframes
atDirectives.description: Defines set of animation key frames.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-any()
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that is represented by the selector list passed as its argument. Standardized as :matches().

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-any-link
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that acts as the source anchor of a hyperlink. Applies to both visited and unvisited links.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-broken
pseudoClasses.description: The :-moz-broken CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches elements representing broken image links.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-drag-over
pseudoClasses.description: The :-moz-drag-over CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches an element when a dragover event is called on it.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-first-node
pseudoClasses.description: The :-moz-first-node CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that represents any element that is the first child node of some other element. It differs from :first-child because it does not match a first-child element with (non-whitespace) text before it.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-focusring
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Matches an element that has focus and focus ring drawing is enabled in the browser.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-full-screen
pseudoClasses.description: Matches any element that has its fullscreen flag set. Standardized as :fullscreen.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-last-node
pseudoClasses.description: The :-moz-last-node CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that represents any element that is the last child node of some other element. It differs from :last-child because it does not match a last-child element with (non-whitespace) text after it.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-loading
pseudoClasses.description: The :-moz-loading CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches elements that can't be displayed because they have not started loading, such as images that haven't started to arrive yet. Note that images that are in the process of loading are not matched by this pseudo-class.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-only-whitespace
pseudoClasses.description: The :-moz-only-whitespace CSS pseudo-class matches elements that only contain text nodes that only contain whitespace. (This includes elements with empty text nodes and elements with no child nodes.)

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-placeholder
pseudoClasses.description: Deprecated. Represents placeholder text in an input field. Use ::-moz-placeholder for Firefox 19+.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-submit-invalid
pseudoClasses.description: The :-moz-submit-invalid CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that represents any submit <button> on forms whose contents aren't valid based on their validation constraints.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-suppressed
pseudoClasses.description: The :-moz-suppressed CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches elements representing images that were suppressed because loading images from the specified site has been blocked.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-ui-invalid
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Represents any validated form element whose value isn't valid

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-ui-valid
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Represents any validated form element whose value is valid

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-user-disabled
pseudoClasses.description: The :-moz-user-disabled CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches elements representing images that were not loaded because images have been entirely disabled by the user's preferences.

pseudoClasses.name: :-moz-window-inactive
pseudoClasses.description: The :-moz-window-inactive CSS pseudo-class is a Mozilla extension that matches any element while it's in an inactive window.

pseudoClasses.name: :-ms-fullscreen
pseudoClasses.description: Matches any element that has its fullscreen flag set.

pseudoClasses.name: :-ms-input-placeholder
pseudoClasses.description: Represents placeholder text in an input field. Note: for Edge use the pseudo-element ::-ms-input-placeholder. Standardized as ::placeholder.

pseudoClasses.name: :-ms-keyboard-active
pseudoClasses.description: Windows Store apps only. Applies one or more styles to an element when it has focus and the user presses the space bar.

pseudoClasses.name: :-ms-lang()
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that is in the language specified. Accepts a comma separated list of language tokens.

pseudoClasses.name: :-webkit-any()
pseudoClasses.description: Represents an element that is represented by the selector list passed as its argument. Standardized as :matches().

pseudoClasses.name: :-webkit-full-screen
pseudoClasses.description: Matches any element that has its fullscreen flag set. Standardized as :fullscreen.

pseudoClasses.name: :active
pseudoClasses.description: The :active CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a button) that is being activated by the user. When using a mouse, "activation" typically starts when the user presses down the primary mouse button.

pseudoClasses.name: :any-link
pseudoClasses.description: The :any-link CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that acts as the source anchor of a hyperlink, independent of whether it has been visited. In other words, it matches every <a> or <area> element that has an href attribute. Thus, it matches all elements that match :link or :visited.

pseudoClasses.name: :blank
pseudoClasses.description: The :blank CSS pseudo-class selects empty user input elements (e.g. <input> or <textarea>).

pseudoClasses.name: :checked
pseudoClasses.description: The :checked CSS pseudo-class selector represents any radio (<input type="radio">), checkbox (<input type="checkbox">), or option (<option> in a <select>) element that is checked or toggled to an on state.

pseudoClasses.name: :corner-present
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Indicates whether or not a scrollbar corner is present.

pseudoClasses.name: :current
pseudoClasses.description: The :current CSS pseudo-class selector is a time-dimensional pseudo-class that represents an element or the ancestor of an element that is currently being displayed. For example, this pseudo-class can be used to represent a video that is being displayed with captions by WebVTT.

pseudoClasses.name: :decrement
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to buttons and track pieces. Indicates whether or not the button or track piece will decrement the view's position when used.

pseudoClasses.name: :default
pseudoClasses.description: The :default CSS pseudo-class selects form elements that are the default in a group of related elements.

pseudoClasses.name: :defined
pseudoClasses.description: The :defined CSS pseudo-class represents any element that has been defined. This includes any standard element built in to the browser, and custom elements that have been successfully defined (i.e. with the CustomElementRegistry.define() method).

pseudoClasses.name: :dir
pseudoClasses.description: The :dir() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the directionality of the text contained in them.

pseudoClasses.name: :disabled
pseudoClasses.description: The :disabled CSS pseudo-class represents any disabled element. An element is disabled if it can't be activated (selected, clicked on, typed into, etc.) or accept focus. The element also has an enabled state, in which it can be activated or accept focus.

pseudoClasses.name: :double-button
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to buttons and track pieces. Applies when both buttons are displayed together at the same end of the scrollbar.

pseudoClasses.name: :empty
pseudoClasses.description: The :empty CSS pseudo-class represents any element that has no children. Children can be either element nodes or text (including whitespace). Comments, processing instructions, and CSS content do not affect whether an element is considered empty.

pseudoClasses.name: :enabled
pseudoClasses.description: The :enabled CSS pseudo-class represents any enabled element. An element is enabled if it can be activated (selected, clicked on, typed into, etc.) or accept focus. The element also has a disabled state, in which it can't be activated or accept focus.

pseudoClasses.name: :end
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to buttons and track pieces. Indicates whether the object is placed after the thumb.

pseudoClasses.name: :first
pseudoClasses.description: The :first CSS pseudo-class, used with the @page at-rule, represents the first page of a printed document. (See :first-child for general first element of a node.)

pseudoClasses.name: :first-child
pseudoClasses.description: The :first-child CSS pseudo-class represents the first element among a group of sibling elements.

pseudoClasses.name: :first-of-type
pseudoClasses.description: The :first-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents the first element of its type among a group of sibling elements.

pseudoClasses.name: :focus
pseudoClasses.description: The :focus CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as a form input) that has received focus. It is generally triggered when the user clicks or taps on an element or selects it with the keyboard's Tab key.

pseudoClasses.name: :focus-visible
pseudoClasses.description: The :focus-visible pseudo-class applies while an element matches the :focus pseudo-class and the UA (User Agent) determines via heuristics that the focus should be made evident on the element. (Many browsers show a "focus ring" by default in this case.)

pseudoClasses.name: :focus-within
pseudoClasses.description: The :focus-within CSS pseudo-class matches an element if the element or any of its descendants are focused. In other words, it represents an element that is itself matched by the :focus pseudo-class or has a descendant that is matched by :focus. (This includes descendants in shadow trees.)

pseudoClasses.name: :fullscreen
pseudoClasses.description: The :fullscreen CSS pseudo-class matches every element which is currently in fullscreen mode. If multiple elements have been put into fullscreen mode, this selects them all.

pseudoClasses.name: :future
pseudoClasses.description: The :future CSS pseudo-class selector is a time-dimensional pseudo-class that will match for any element which appears entirely after an element that matches :current. For example in a video with captions which are being displayed by WebVTT.

pseudoClasses.name: :has
pseudoClasses.description: :The :has() CSS pseudo-class represents an element if any of the selectors passed as parameters (relative to the :scope of the given element), match at least one element.

pseudoClasses.name: :horizontal
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to any scrollbar pieces that have a horizontal orientation.

pseudoClasses.name: :host
pseudoClasses.description: The :host CSS pseudo-class selects the shadow host of the shadow DOM containing the CSS it is used inside — in other words, this allows you to select a custom element from inside its shadow DOM.

pseudoClasses.name: :host()
pseudoClasses.description: The :host() CSS pseudo-class function selects the shadow host of the shadow DOM containing the CSS it is used inside (so you can select a custom element from inside its shadow DOM) — but only if the selector given as the function's parameter matches the shadow host.

pseudoClasses.name: :host-context()
pseudoClasses.description: The :host-context() CSS pseudo-class function selects the shadow host of the shadow DOM containing the CSS it is used inside (so you can select a custom element from inside its shadow DOM) — but only if the selector given as the function's parameter matches the shadow host's ancestor(s) in the place it sits inside the DOM hierarchy.

pseudoClasses.name: :hover
pseudoClasses.description: The :hover CSS pseudo-class matches when the user interacts with an element with a pointing device, but does not necessarily activate it. It is generally triggered when the user hovers over an element with the cursor (mouse pointer).

pseudoClasses.name: :in-range
pseudoClasses.description: The :in-range CSS pseudo-class represents an <input> element whose current value is within the range limits specified by the min and max attributes.

pseudoClasses.name: :increment
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to buttons and track pieces. Indicates whether or not the button or track piece will increment the view's position when used.

pseudoClasses.name: :indeterminate
pseudoClasses.description: The :indeterminate CSS pseudo-class represents any form element whose state is indeterminate, such as checkboxes which have their HTML indeterminate attribute set to true, radio buttons which are members of a group in which all radio buttons are unchecked, and indeterminate <progress> elements.

pseudoClasses.name: :invalid
pseudoClasses.description: The :invalid CSS pseudo-class represents any <form>, <fieldset>, <input> or other <form> element whose contents fail to validate.

pseudoClasses.name: :is
pseudoClasses.description: The :is() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list. This is useful for writing large selectors in a more compact form.

pseudoClasses.name: :lang()
pseudoClasses.description: The :lang() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the language they are determined to be in.

pseudoClasses.name: :last-child
pseudoClasses.description: The :last-child CSS pseudo-class represents the last element among a group of sibling elements.

pseudoClasses.name: :last-of-type
pseudoClasses.description: The :last-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents the last element of its type among a group of sibling elements.

pseudoClasses.name: :left
pseudoClasses.description: The :left CSS pseudo-class, used with the @page at-rule, represents all left-hand pages of a printed document.

pseudoClasses.name: :link
pseudoClasses.description: The :link CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has not yet been visited. It matches every unvisited <a> or <area> element that has an href attribute.

pseudoClasses.name: :local-link
pseudoClasses.description: The :local-link CSS pseudo-class represents a link to the same document. Therefore an element that is the source anchor of a hyperlink whose target's absolute URL matches the element's own document URL.

pseudoClasses.name: :matches()
pseudoClasses.description: Takes a selector list as its argument. It represents an element that is represented by its argument.

pseudoClasses.name: :no-button
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to track pieces. Applies when there is no button at that end of the track.

pseudoClasses.name: :not()
pseudoClasses.description: The :not() CSS pseudo-class represents elements that do not match a list of selectors. Since it prevents specific items from being selected, it is known as the negation pseudo-class.

pseudoClasses.name: :nth-child()
pseudoClasses.description: The :nth-child() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on the indexes of the elements in the child list of their parents. In other words, the :nth-child() selector selects child elements according to their position among all the sibling elements within a parent element.

pseudoClasses.name: :nth-col
pseudoClasses.description: The :nth-col() CSS pseudo-class is designed for tables and grids. It accepts the An+B notation such as used with the :nth-child selector, using this to target every nth column.

pseudoClasses.name: :nth-last-child()
pseudoClasses.description: The :nth-last-child() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position among a group of siblings, counting from the end.

pseudoClasses.name: :nth-last-col
pseudoClasses.description: The :nth-last-col() CSS pseudo-class is designed for tables and grids. It accepts the An+B notation such as used with the :nth-child selector, using this to target every nth column before it, therefore counting back from the end of the set of columns.

pseudoClasses.name: :nth-last-of-type()
pseudoClasses.description: The :nth-last-of-type() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position among siblings of the same type (tag name), counting from the end.

pseudoClasses.name: :nth-of-type()
pseudoClasses.description: The :nth-of-type() CSS pseudo-class matches elements based on their position among siblings of the same type (tag name).

pseudoClasses.name: :only-child
pseudoClasses.description: The :only-child CSS pseudo-class represents an element without any siblings. This is the same as :first-child:last-child or :nth-child(1):nth-last-child(1), but with a lower specificity.

pseudoClasses.name: :only-of-type
pseudoClasses.description: The :only-of-type CSS pseudo-class represents an element that has no siblings of the same type.

pseudoClasses.name: :optional
pseudoClasses.description: The :optional CSS pseudo-class represents any <input>, <select>, or <textarea> element that does not have the required attribute set on it.

pseudoClasses.name: :out-of-range
pseudoClasses.description: The :out-of-range CSS pseudo-class represents an <input> element whose current value is outside the range limits specified by the min and max attributes.

pseudoClasses.name: :past
pseudoClasses.description: The :past CSS pseudo-class selector is a time-dimensional pseudo-class that will match for any element which appears entirely before an element that matches :current. For example in a video with captions which are being displayed by WebVTT.

pseudoClasses.name: :paused
pseudoClasses.description: The :paused CSS pseudo-class selector represents an element that is playable, such as <audio> or <video>, when that element is "paused" (i.e. not "playing").

pseudoClasses.name: :picture-in-picture
pseudoClasses.description: The :picture-in-picture CSS pseudo-class matches the element which is currently in picture-in-picture mode.

pseudoClasses.name: :placeholder-shown
pseudoClasses.description: The :placeholder-shown CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or <textarea> element that is currently displaying placeholder text.

pseudoClasses.name: :playing
pseudoClasses.description:
The :playing CSS pseudo-class selector represents the playback state of an element that is playable, such as <audio> or <video>, when that element is "playing".
  An element is considered to be playing if it is currently playing the media resource, or if it has temporarily stopped for reasons other than user intent (such as :buffering or :stalled).

pseudoClasses.name: :read-only
pseudoClasses.description: The :read-only CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as input or textarea) that is not editable by the user.

pseudoClasses.name: :read-write
pseudoClasses.description: The :read-write CSS pseudo-class represents an element (such as input or textarea) that is editable by the user.

pseudoClasses.name: :required
pseudoClasses.description: The :required CSS pseudo-class represents any <input>, <select>, or <textarea> element that has the required attribute set on it.

pseudoClasses.name: :right
pseudoClasses.description: The :right CSS pseudo-class, used with the @page at-rule, represents all right-hand pages of a printed document.

pseudoClasses.name: :root
pseudoClasses.description: The :root CSS pseudo-class matches the root element of a tree representing the document. In HTML, :root represents the <html> element and is identical to the selector html, except that its specificity is higher.

pseudoClasses.name: :scope
pseudoClasses.description: The :scope CSS pseudo-class represents elements that are a reference point, or scope, for selectors to match against.

pseudoClasses.name: :single-button
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to buttons and track pieces. Applies when both buttons are displayed separately at either end of the scrollbar.

pseudoClasses.name: :start
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to buttons and track pieces. Indicates whether the object is placed before the thumb.

pseudoClasses.name: :target
pseudoClasses.description: The :target CSS pseudo-class represents a unique element (the target element) with an id matching the URL's fragment.

pseudoClasses.name: :target-within
pseudoClasses.description: The :target-within CSS pseudo-class represents an element that is a target element or contains an element that is a target. A target element is a unique element with an id matching the URL's fragment. In other words, it represents an element that is itself matched by the :target pseudo-class or has a descendant that is matched by :target. (This includes descendants in shadow trees.)

pseudoClasses.name: :user-invalid
pseudoClasses.description: The :user-invalid CSS pseudo-class represents any validated form element whose value isn't valid based on their validation constraints, after the user has interacted with it.

pseudoClasses.name: :user-valid
pseudoClasses.description: The :user-valid CSS pseudo-class represents any validated form element whose value validates correctly based on its validation constraints. However, unlike :valid it only matches once the user has interacted with it.

pseudoClasses.name: :valid
pseudoClasses.description: The :valid CSS pseudo-class represents any <input> or other <form> element whose contents validate successfully. This allows to easily make valid fields adopt an appearance that helps the user confirm that their data is formatted properly.

pseudoClasses.name: :vertical
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to any scrollbar pieces that have a vertical orientation.

pseudoClasses.name: :visited
pseudoClasses.description: The :visited CSS pseudo-class applies once the link has been visited by the user. For privacy reasons, the styles that can be modified using this selector are very limited. The :visited pseudo-class applies only <a> and <area> elements that have an href attribute.

pseudoClasses.name: :where
pseudoClasses.description: The :where() CSS pseudo-class function takes a selector list as its argument, and selects any element that can be selected by one of the selectors in that list.

pseudoClasses.name: :window-inactive
pseudoClasses.description: Non-standard. Applies to all scrollbar pieces. Indicates whether or not the window containing the scrollbar is currently active.

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-focus-inner
pseudoElements.description: The ::-moz-focus-inner CSS pseudo-element is a Mozilla extension that represents an inner focus ring of the <button> element as well as the button, submit, reset, and color types of the <input> element.

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-focus-outer
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-list-bullet
pseudoElements.description: The ::-moz-list-bullet CSS pseudo-element is a Mozilla extension that represents the marker (typically a bullet) of a list item (<li>) in an unordered list (<ul>).

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-list-number
pseudoElements.description: The ::-moz-list-number CSS pseudo-element is a Mozilla extension that represents the marker (typically a number) of a list item (<li>) in an ordered list (<ol>).

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-placeholder
pseudoElements.description: Represents placeholder text in an input field

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-progress-bar
pseudoElements.description: The ::-moz-progress-bar CSS pseudo-element is a Mozilla extension that represents the progress bar inside a <progress> element. (The bar represents the amount of progress that has been made.)

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-range-progress
pseudoElements.description: The ::-moz-range-progress CSS pseudo-element is a Mozilla extension that represents the lower portion of the track (i.e., groove) in which the indicator slides in an <input> of type="range". This portion corresponds to values lower than the value currently selected by the thumb (i.e., virtual knob).

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-range-thumb
pseudoElements.description: The ::-moz-range-thumb CSS pseudo-element is a Mozilla extension that represents the thumb (i.e., virtual knob) of an <input> of type="range". The user can move the thumb along the input's track to alter its numerical value.

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-range-track
pseudoElements.description: The ::-moz-range-track CSS pseudo-element is a Mozilla extension that represents the track (i.e., groove) in which the indicator slides in an <input> of type="range".

pseudoElements.name: ::-moz-selection
pseudoElements.description: Represents the portion of a document that has been highlighted by the user.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-backdrop
pseudoElements.description: Used to create a backdrop that hides the underlying document for an element in a top layer (such as an element that is displayed fullscreen).

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-browse
pseudoElements.description: Represents the browse button of an input type=file control.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-check
pseudoElements.description: Represents the check of a checkbox or radio button input control.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-clear
pseudoElements.description: Represents the clear button of a text input control

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-expand
pseudoElements.description: Represents the drop-down button of a select control.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-fill
pseudoElements.description: Represents the bar portion of a progress bar.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-fill-lower
pseudoElements.description: Represents the portion of the slider track from its smallest value up to the value currently selected by the thumb. In a left-to-right layout, this is the portion of the slider track to the left of the thumb.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-fill-upper
pseudoElements.description: Represents the portion of the slider track from the value currently selected by the thumb up to the slider's largest value. In a left-to-right layout, this is the portion of the slider track to the right of the thumb.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-reveal
pseudoElements.description: Represents the password reveal button of an input type=password control.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-thumb
pseudoElements.description: Represents the portion of range input control (also known as a slider control) that the user drags.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-ticks-after
pseudoElements.description: Represents the tick marks of a slider that begin just after the thumb and continue up to the slider's largest value. In a left-to-right layout, these are the ticks to the right of the thumb.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-ticks-before
pseudoElements.description: Represents the tick marks of a slider that represent its smallest values up to the value currently selected by the thumb. In a left-to-right layout, these are the ticks to the left of the thumb.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-tooltip
pseudoElements.description: Represents the tooltip of a slider (input type=range).

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-track
pseudoElements.description: Represents the track of a slider.

pseudoElements.name: ::-ms-value
pseudoElements.description: Represents the content of a text or password input control, or a select control.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-file-upload-button
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-inner-spin-button
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-inner-spin-button CSS pseudo-element is used to style the inner part of the spinner button of number picker input elements.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-input-placeholder
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-keygen-select
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-meter-bar
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-meter-bar CSS pseudo-element is a WebKit extension that represents the meter bar in a <meter> element. It is used for selecting and applying styles to the container meter gauge.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-meter-even-less-good-value
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-meter-even-less-good-value gives a red color to a <meter> element when the value and the optimum attributes fall outside the low-high range, but in opposite zones. To illustrate, it applies when value < low < high < optimum or value > high > low > optimum.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-meter-optimum-value
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-meter-optimum-value CSS pseudo-element styles the <meter> element when its value is inside the low-high range.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-meter-suboptimum-value
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-meter-suboptimum-value pseudo-element gives a yellow color to the <meter> element when the value attribute falls outside of the low-high range.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-outer-spin-button
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-outer-spin-button CSS pseudo-element is used to style the outer part of the spinner button of number picker <input> elements.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-progress-bar
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-progress-bar CSS pseudo-element represents the entire bar of a <progress> element. Normally it's only visible as the unfilled portion of the bar, since by default it's rendered below the ::-webkit-progress-value pseudo-element. It is a child of the ::-webkit-progress-inner-element pseudo-element and the parent of the ::-webkit-progress-value pseudo-element.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-progress-inner-element
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-progress-inner-element CSS pseudo-element represents the outermost container of the <progress> element. It is the parent of the ::-webkit-progress-bar pseudo-element.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-progress-inner-value
pseudoElements.description:
The ::-webkit-progress-value CSS pseudo-element represents the filled-in portion of the bar of a <progress> element. It is a child of the ::-webkit-progress-bar pseudo-element.

In order to let ::-webkit-progress-value take effect, -webkit-appearance needs to be set to none on the <progress> element.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-progress-value
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-progress-value CSS pseudo-element represents the filled-in portion of the bar of a <progress> element. It is a child of the ::-webkit-progress-bar pseudo-element.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-resizer
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-scrollbar
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-scrollbar CSS pseudo-element affects the style of an element's scrollbar when it has overflow:scroll; set.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-scrollbar-button
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-scrollbar-corner
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-scrollbar-track
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-scrollbar-track-piece
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-search-cancel-button
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-search-cancel-button CSS pseudo-element represents a button (the "cancel button") at the edge of an <input> of type="search" which clears away the current value of the <input> element. This button and pseudo-element are non-standard, supported only in WebKit and Blink, hence the vendor prefix. The clear button is only shown on non-empty search <input> elements.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-search-decoration
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-search-results-button
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-search-results-button CSS pseudo-element represents a button (the "search results button") at the left edge of an <input> of type="search" which when clicked displays a menu which allows the user to choose from previous recent search queries. This button and pseudo-element are non-standard, supported only in WebKit and Blink, hence the vendor prefix. The search results button is only shown on search <input> elements that have a results attribute.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-search-results-decoration
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-slider-runnable-track
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-slider-runnable-track CSS pseudo-element represents the "track" (the groove in which the indicator slides) of an <input type="range">.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-slider-thumb
pseudoElements.description: The ::-webkit-slider-thumb CSS pseudo-element represents the "thumb" that the user can move within the "groove" of an <input> of type="range" to alter its numerical value.

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-textfield-decoration-container
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-validation-bubble
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-validation-bubble-arrow
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-validation-bubble-arrow-clipper
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-validation-bubble-heading
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-validation-bubble-message
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::-webkit-validation-bubble-text-block
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::after
pseudoElements.description: In CSS, ::after creates a pseudo-element that is the last child of the selected element. It is often used to add cosmetic content to an element with the content property. It is inline by default.

pseudoElements.name: ::backdrop
pseudoElements.description: The ::backdrop CSS pseudo-element is a box the size of the viewport, which is rendered immediately beneath any element being presented in the top layer.

pseudoElements.name: ::before
pseudoElements.description: In CSS, ::before creates a pseudo-element that is the first child of the selected element. It is often used to add cosmetic content to an element with the content property. It is inline by default.

pseudoElements.name: ::content
pseudoElements.description: Deprecated. Matches the distribution list itself, on elements that have one. Use ::slotted for forward compatibility.

pseudoElements.name: ::cue
pseudoElements.description: The ::cue CSS pseudo-element matches WebVTT cues within a selected element. This can be used to style captions and other cues in media with VTT tracks.

pseudoElements.name: ::cue()
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::cue-region
pseudoElements.description: The ::cue-region CSS pseudo-element matches WebVTT cues within a selected element. This can be used to style captions and other cues in media with VTT tracks.

pseudoElements.name: ::cue-region()
pseudoElements.description: No description on MDN

pseudoElements.name: ::first-letter
pseudoElements.description: The ::first-letter CSS pseudo-element applies styles to the first letter of the first line of a block-level element, but only when not preceded by other content (such as images or inline tables).

pseudoElements.name: ::first-line
pseudoElements.description: The ::first-line CSS pseudo-element applies styles to the first line of a block-level element.

pseudoElements.name: ::grammar-error
pseudoElements.description: The ::grammar-error CSS pseudo-element represents a text segment which the user agent has flagged as grammatically incorrect.

pseudoElements.name: ::marker
pseudoElements.description: The ::marker CSS pseudo-element selects the marker box of a list item, which typically contains a bullet or number. It works on any element or pseudo-element set to display: list-item, such as the <li> and <summary> elements.

pseudoElements.name: ::part
pseudoElements.description: The ::part CSS pseudo-element represents any element within a shadow tree that has a matching part attribute.

pseudoElements.name: ::placeholder
pseudoElements.description: The ::placeholder CSS pseudo-element represents the placeholder text in an <input> or <textarea> element.

pseudoElements.name: ::selection
pseudoElements.description: The ::selection CSS pseudo-element applies styles to the part of a document that has been highlighted by the user (such as clicking and dragging the mouse across text).

pseudoElements.name: ::shadow
pseudoElements.description: Matches the shadow root if an element has a shadow tree.

pseudoElements.name: ::slotted
pseudoElements.description: The :slotted() CSS pseudo-element represents any element that has been placed into a slot inside an HTML template.

pseudoElements.name: ::spelling-error
pseudoElements.description: The ::spelling-error CSS pseudo-element represents a text segment which the user agent has flagged as incorrectly spelled.

pseudoElements.name: ::target-text
pseudoElements.description: The ::target-text CSS pseudo-element represents the text that has been scrolled to if the browser supports text fragments. It allows authors to choose how to highlight that section of text.

pseudoElements.name: ::view-transition
pseudoElements.description: The ::view-transition CSS pseudo-element represents the root of the view transitions overlay, which contains all view transitions and sits over the top of all other page content.

pseudoElements.name: ::view-transition-group
pseudoElements.description: The ::view-transition-group CSS pseudo-element represents a single view transition group.

pseudoElements.name: ::view-transition-image-pair
pseudoElements.description: The ::view-transition-image-pair CSS pseudo-element represents a container for a view transition's "old" and "new" view states — before and after the transition.

pseudoElements.name: ::view-transition-new
pseudoElements.description: The ::view-transition-new CSS pseudo-element represents the "new" view state of a view transition — a live representation of the new view, after the transition.

pseudoElements.name: ::view-transition-old
pseudoElements.description: The ::view-transition-old CSS pseudo-element represents the "old" view state of a view transition — a static screenshot of the old view, before the transition.
